title: d%C3%BAn laoghaire rathdown council faces government intervention over move to block homes
story: Minister of State for local government Peter Burke has been asked to issue formal directions to the council compelling it to take action over breaches of  recommendations.  Photograph: Tom HonanDún Laoghaire-Rathdown County Council is facing a Government intervention over its contentious move to block new homes being built in the south Dublin suburbs of Killiney and Dalkey, as a row intensifies over the future of some of the most valuable lands in the State.Planning regulators objected to the ban, arguing it was “an unnecessary restriction” on sustainable development. But councillors refused to remove the measure from their 2022-28 development plan, in defiance of the regulator’s statutory recommendations to overturn it. Now regulator Niall Cussen has asked Minister of State for local government Peter Burke to issue formal directions to the council compelling it to take action over breaches of such recommendations. The development plan says “significant parts” of Dalkey and Killiney are characterised by low density development, adding that “no increase in the number of residential buildings will normally be permitted” in some areas. In correspondence to the Minister late last week, Mr Cussen has also asked him to issue directions over new restrictions on buy-to-let apartments in the development plan. The regulator opposed measures that require three-bedroom apartments to be built in 40 per cent of the units in build-to-rent schemes in “new residential communities”.Mr Burke is understood to be preparing to issue draft directions on both counts in coming days, meaning the matter will go back to the council. That move essentially means the council will have to reopen the development plan it adopted last month, after 18 months of debate.The Office of the Planning Regulator (OPR) was established in 2019 to provide independent oversight of the planning process. One of its functions is to assess development plans to ensure they properly apply national policies.City and county councils around the State are in the process of adopting a new wave of development plans, which sets the framework for housing and other developments for the rest of the decade.Mr Cussen’s call for a ministerial direction in the Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown plan is his sixth. He previously asked the Minister to intervene in the plans of Cork County Council and the councils in Kilkenny, Laois, Meath and Westmeath. Asked about the regulator’s decision on its plan, Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown council said any notification seeking a ministerial direction goes to the Minister and not it as the planning authority. “The Minister then has two weeks in which to issue notice of any intention to issue a direction to the planning authority. That further two-week period has not yet passed,” the council said.The regulator’s office had no comment on its decision, which follows a four-week review of the development plan. Any ministerial direction “commences a process by the local authority, including public consultation, after which the OPR further considers the matter with a view to recommending, or not, that the Minister issue a final direction” on the plan.“The OPR works proactively with local authorities in the deliberations on their plans to ensure the best outcomes for communities which are consistent with regional and national planning policies.”Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: jim wells resigns from dup after 46 years
story: Jim Wells poses in election photographs with TUV candidate Harold McKee and TUV leader Jim Allister. Photograph: TUVPA WireVeteran DUP representative Jim Wells has resigned from the party after 46 years.Mr Wells, a former health minister, told the BBC Nolan Show he could not support the Democratic Unionist Party’s candidate in South Down for the Assembly elections, Diane Forsythe. Mr Wells instead declared his support for a candidate from the rival Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV) in the Stormont elections.He said: “I have decided I cannot support the candidate that the party executive has imposed on the people of South Down and I have resigned from the party.“I think that the moment I said that I would not be backing the candidate that was imposed upon us, it was inevitable.“I took the decision late last night to contact the party leader, the party secretary and the chief executive and let them know that after 46 years I have gone as a DUP member.“I feel very strongly about this.”Mr Wells, who has been the DUP’s Assembly representative in South Down since 1998, has called on voters to give their first preference to Harold McKee of the TUV on May 5th.The DUP responded by stating the election was about more than “mere personalities”.Mr Wells found out earlier this year he had not been selected as the party’s candidate for the South Down constituency after Ms Forsythe was chosen as the candidate.Mr Wells had been vocal in his opposition to Ms Forsythe as the candidate, and instead backed a failed bid by former DUP leader Edwin Poots to become the party’s candidate in the area.He has posed in election photographs with Mr McKee and TUV leader Jim Allister. ‘Core principles’Mr Wells said: “As I leave the Assembly it is my earnest desire that South Down should continue to have a Unionist MLA whose politics are grounded in conviction and principle.“Among the candidates Harold McKee is the stand-out candidate with these credentials.“He holds dear many of the core principles that I upheld in Stormont and is widely and properly respected as a politician of conviction, not expediency.“Accordingly, I recommend him to those who faithfully supported me at the polls over the years and urge them to vote McKee 1.”Mr McKee said Mr Wells had been “abandoned by his own party”.He added: “I am delighted to have his support and gratified that a broad swathe of unionism is uniting behind me as the standard bearer of principled unionism.”TUV leader Jim Allister said: “At critical times in Stormont, Jim Wells was often the only MLA prepared to join me in doing what was right.“Putting party advantage before principle would have been easy, but Jim did the right thing and likewise today in backing Harold he is putting principle before party.”A DUP spokesperson said: “This election is much more important than mere personalities. The seat totals after the count will decide whether NI goes in the right or wrong direction and our priorities for the next five years.“Diane Forsythe secured the DUP’s best ever result in South Down in 2017.“She is a young mother, rooted in the Mournes with a plan for South Down. Diane will focus on what matters to people.” – PA

title: frances populist revolt coming
story: What did they mean by that? The French public has delivered a first-round result in their presidential election that leaves political nerds unable to reach a consensus about where events are likely to go from here.On the one hand, a four-point margin for the incumbent Emmanuel Macron over Marine Le Pen was bigger than some polls had predicted. The Western world’s “centrist dad” brigade might have been inclined to breathe a sigh of relief and claim there is no discernible path to victory for Madame Le Pen in the second-round run-off in a fortnight’s time.But the centrist dads have been wrong before – about Brexit, about Donald Trump and about Britain’s 2019 general election, to cite just a few recent examples. There is at least as strong a case for looking at yesterday’s result and concluding that the establishment-minded centre cannot hold and that it is now not a question of whether there will be a populist Right takeover of the apparatus of government in France, but merely of when.For a start, there is a simple comparison to be made with the first-round vote of five years ago. Back then the charismatic insurgent Macron won 24 per cent, to Le Pen’s 21 per cent. Half a decade has added an unspectacular two or three percentage points to the vote shares of both and the same to Jean-Luc Melenchon, the far-Left populist who scored 19.5 per cent five years ago and 22 per cent last night.But look at what has happened to the traditional establishment parties of centre-Left and centre-Right, the Socialists and the Republicans. Five years ago the former was thought to be at its lowest possible ebb when its candidate won just six per cent, while the latter was deeply disappointed with a 20 per cent share. Last night those scores slumped to two per cent and five per cent respectively.So France is in a vigorously anti-establishment mood and it is hard to see how five years of incumbency and presidential peacocking will enable Macron to harness that as well as he did in 2017. There is a widespread feeling that he is a “president of the rich” with an entourage dominated by privileged young Parisians swanning around in made-to-measure suits and harbouring luxury liberal beliefs.Le Pen, by contrast, has sought out the populist sweet spot of being to the Right on cultural issues and to the Left on economic ones. Her campaign has taken her around the market towns of France, speaking to the common people who formed the bulk of the “Gilet Jaune” protestors and who care more about the price of petrol than the high politics of EU summits or even the suffering of Ukraine.In the first round this time, Le Pen has not only established a strong lead among working class voters but also among the young, with a radical plan to scrap income tax for the under-30s being the core of of her economic offering.Macron himself appears to understand that he will not win the run-off as a conventional capital city centrist given the current public mood and last night pledged to represent the aspirations of those who voted for Le Pen and her fellow Right populist Eric Zemmour, the bulk of whose seven per cent vote share is surely currently heading her way.The decisive factor now will be where the voters of Melenchon end up. Many despise the values of the Paris-based elites just as much as Le Pen’s supporters do and many also are firmly traditionalist on social and cultural matters. Last night Melenchon did Macron a favour by urging them not to vote for Le Pen, though he could not bring himself to endorse the French president.The next two weeks will see French elites attempt to kill Le Pen’s ambitions in the usual way – using her surname and previous leadership of the Front National against her, as well as her unwise past praise for Vladimir Putin, in a bid to persuade voters that she is simply not a respectable choice.But Macron himself seems to understand that, barring Le Pen malfunctioning disastrously again in a televised debate as she did last time, this will not be enough. During his first term Macron has tried hard to keep onboard voters who are anxious about the state of French society and has made a series of speeches about enforcing integration into the French way of life for migrant communities.If he holds on in two weeks’ time – as he is just about favourite to do – it will surely be because he remains a sufficiently canny campaigner to keep one foot in the populist camp himself rather than because the French public are gravitating back towards establishment norms.Nobody expects anything like the crushing two-to-one drubbing he gave Le Pen in the run-off last time. Even if they beat her this time, how the French establishment would fend her off again in 2027 is very difficult to see.More from NewsPolitics latest news: More than 50 Downing Street &#39partygate&#39 fines issued, say Met PoliceRussia-Ukraine latest news: Vladimir Putin vows ‘clear and noble’ aims of Russian invasion will be achievedTory MPs call on Ben Goldsmith to quit after voicing support for Extinction RebellionRescuers dig for suvivors after storm Megi brings landslides to PhilippinesBan export of UK&#39s rubbish overseas, says Environment Agency chiefSocial media to be considered suicide risk factor for first timeMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: gallery highlights male gaze manet masterpiece woke attempt
story: The “male gaze” in a Manet masterpiece has been highlighted by the Courtauld Gallery after curators introduced new labels addressing “misogyny” in art.The London gallery, which holds the UK’s foremost Impressionist collection, reviewed the labelling of all of its paintings as part of a three-year, £57 million refurbishment. Some information panels now address issues like artists’ racism and sexism.Manet's masterpiece, A Bar at the Folies-Bergère, has been reinterpreted with a new label which suggests that the painting has an “unsettling” quality, because of the presence of a man on the canvas.The 1882 work depicts a barmaid staring out at the viewer of the painting and - in a mirrored image - towards a male patron of the eponymous Folies-Bergère (a Parisian cabaret club) who returns her gaze.The female subject’s “enigmatic expression is unsettling”, a new information panel states, “especially as she appears to be interacting with a male customer”.The suggestion that an “unsettling” quality of the painting is enhanced because the woman talking to a man has been criticised for unwitting “misogyny”, because it diminishes the position of the female model in the work.Ruth Millington, a historian whose book Muse chronicles the female inspirations for great art, said: “It completely shifts the viewer’s attention away from her and onto the man in the picture.“This interpretation, in a woke attempt to call out misogyny, unwittingly centres the male gaze. The writer implies that the woman is unsettled by the man’s presence, framing her as a passive victim of her circumstances.“Curators must stop trapping female muses and models with male-centred interpretations such as this.“In a painting of multiple gazes, it’s unfair and misogynistic to emphasise the male perspective. I’d rather read a fresh new label which invites viewers to imagine what the woman is thinking.”The model Manet used for the painting was a real-life woman called Suzon who worked at the Folies-Bergère, a venue frequented where prostitutes plied their trade, and it has been suggested that a subtext of the painting is the exploited barmaid’s availability to male customers, along with the alcohol she is selling.The Courtauld holds the UK’s leading collection of Gauguin works, but the French painter known for his time in Tahitian subjects - and teenage brides -  has now been reappraised by curators for “taking advantage of his position as a European coloniser”.A label on his Post-Impressionist work Nevermore states the painting depicts “one of several teenagers that he took on as ‘wives’”, adding that “the widespread racist fantasy of Tahitian girls as sexually precocious led to their unabashed exploitation”.An information panel for his 1897 painting Te Rerioa now informs visitors that its subject matter was intended to “appeal to a white European audience” by “exoticising” Polynesians.Further information on Gauguin’s memoir Avant et Apres - recently acquired by the Courtauld - states that the 213-page manuscript is “peppered with examples of his own racism and misogyny”.The treatment of other cultures as “primitive” has also been addressed in a new label for the self-portrait of Roger Fry, the Bloomsbury group painter, known for his advancement of Gauguin-inspired “Primitivism” in Western art.Updated information on the portrait states: “For modernist artists and writers, African art belonged to an earlier stage of civilisation known as “primitivism ““This reveals the reactive ideas of the time, which underpinned even the views of progressives like Fry.”The Courtauld’s relabelling comes following widespread reassessment of problematic artists, with the Picasso Museum in Paris recently inviting artists to critique the painter’s personal life, and the National Gallery highlighting Gauguin’s sexual proclivities in a 2019 show.Manet has also faced reappraisal over works like Olympia, a bold nude that scandalised the Paris Salon in 1865, and which has invited more recent criticism at the Musée d’Orsay for its sidelining of a black woman in the painting.The Courtauld has been contacted for comment.More from NewsPolitics latest news: More than 50 Downing Street &#39partygate&#39 fines issued, say Met PoliceRussia-Ukraine latest news: Vladimir Putin vows ‘clear and noble’ aims of Russian invasion will be achievedTory MPs call on Ben Goldsmith to quit after voicing support for Extinction RebellionRescuers dig for suvivors after storm Megi brings landslides to PhilippinesBan export of UK&#39s rubbish overseas, says Environment Agency chiefSocial media to be considered suicide risk factor for first timeMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: britons facing 12 months travel delays due staff shortages
story: Travellers are facing up to 12 months of delays at Britain’s airports and ports as the travel industry struggles to recruit enough people to fill vacancies, industry experts have warned.Kully Sandhu, the managing director of the Aviation Recruitment Network, told the BBC’s Today Programme that it will take “at least the next 12 months for the industry, vacancy wise, to settle down.”Thousands of people heading abroad for the Easter holidays have been warned they face long queues, delays and cancellations.Manchester Airport, along with others, has warned that long waits at security could continue as it struggles with staff shortages, with some passengers facing queues of 60 to 90 minutes over the next few weeks.Industry leaders have said the lack of staff is the primary cause of the issue, the both the pandemic and Brexit leading to a shortage of workers.“Brexit has not helped because we had a natural attraction of iniduals from the European market who would apply for vacancies in UK airports. We no longer have that talent pool, and we are relying on iniduals in the UK,” Mr Sandhu told the BBC. “It makes it very difficult for recruiters to recruit these iniduals because we are all fighting for the same type of candidates.”Those returning to the UK this week will also face the misery of long queues as Border Force have warned they too have a lack of staff available to check inbound passengers.Lucy Moreton, the General Secretary of the Immigration Services Union, told the BBC that the agency was struggling with a chronic shortage of officers.“For the first time in living memory, Border Force isn’t attracting the number of candidates to fill the vacancies they’ve got,” she said.Ms Moreton warned that this, combined with the particularly large numbers of people travelling over the school holidays, would mean “the queues will move from security based outbound, to Border Force based coming in.”Last month, Heathrow Airport recorded its busiest month since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, with 4.2 million passengers passing through the terminal, an eight-fold increase from the same month in 2021. That figure is expected to rise again this month owing to the Easter holidays as well as the government’s removal of all pandemic-era travel restrictions.However, both Mr Sandhu and Ms Moreton rejected calls for security checks to be loosened during the hiring process, saying the checks were vital to protect the UK’s national security.“You don’t expect your police officer to be incompletely trained or not security cleared and we certainly wouldn’t want anything else for Border Force.” “More resources would enable those checks to get through quicker, but we can’t cut corners on the training so we are looking at a very difficult summer.”More from NewsRussia-Ukraine title: comes next imran khan
story: On Sunday evening, as dusk fell and the Ramadan fast ended, the streets of Pakistan’s cities filled with people waving flags bearing the red and green logo of Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, the party founded by Imran Khan. From Karachi to Lahore, Islamabad to Peshawar – and even in Hyde Park in London – tens of thousands took to the streets to protest the ousting of 69-year-old Khan, the prime minister, after four years in government. Dismissed in the early hours of Sunday, after losing a no-confidence vote in parliament, he is to be replaced as prime minister by Shahbaz Sharif, a politician from the opposition alliance.  But the former international sportsman has not gone gently. Instead, Khan has fought tooth and nail to prevent the vote from going ahead, insisting that he was the victim of a US plot. Last week, moreover, he attempted to dissolve parliament and call fresh elections, a move Pakistan’s Supreme Court declared unconstitutional.  “Part of the issue at play is Khan’s competitive streak,” says Michael Kugelman, deputy director of the Asia programme at the Washington-based Wilson Center. “He’s retained a win-at-all-costs mentality from his cricket days, and in the political sphere this translates to holding on to power as long as he can.”It is the latest chapter in an extraordinary political journey for a man who first came to fame as a cricket star and socialite, but transformed into a populist firebrand who rails against western decadence, panders to the conservative religious lobby, and jails political opponents. Like Donald Trump, he was a celebrity before he was a politician, and like Trump, he has relied on the politics of grievance to gain mass appeal.Khan began his international cricket career at the age of 18 in a 1971 Test series against England, and in 1992 he led Pakistan’s team to a glorious victory in the World Cup. Strikingly handsome, he studied at Oxford, and became a fixture in London’s aristocratic social scene. He was friends with Princess Diana and Mark Shand, the brother of Camilla Parker Bowles, and throughout the 1970s and 1980s was regularly snapped by paparazzi on nights out at Annabelle’s and Tramp.Although he rejected the labels of ‘playboy’ or ‘sex symbol’ in interviews, he was linked with a string of famous women. One iconic photograph showed Khan in a dressing gown in his Chelsea bedroom, with gold tigers adorning the wall behind him. And in his 2009 biography of Khan, Christopher Sandford writes: “Imran may not have been the first player to enjoy his own cult following, but he was more or less singlehandedly responsible for sexualising what had hitherto been an austere, male-oriented activity.”That phase culminated in 1995, when at the age of 43, Khan married 21-year-old Jemima Goldsmith, the daughter of tycoon Jimmy Goldsmith, cementing his place in London’s high society.Then in 1996 – perhaps inspired in part by his new father-in-law who had just established the Referendum Party – Khan founded Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaaf (PTI), which translates to the Movement for Justice. In its first election, the PTI did not win a single seat, and Khan was broadly seen as a joke candidate. He was memorably described by opponents as “Im the Dim”.Undeterred, Khan kept at it, and at the next election, he won a single seat – his own.Despite the early mockery, that lack of political acumen was ultimately a strength. Khan wasn’t coming to politics to make money or a name for himself, explains journalist Aatish Taseer, who has written extensively on Khan. “In a country used to mercenary politicians, this was refreshing.”It was not until the 2013 election campaign that Khan really began to gather mass support, drawing tens of thousands of people to rallies across the country. Appealing primarily to the young, urban middle class – a broadly conservative demographic in Pakistan – Khan pledged to end corruption in 90 days and to create 10 million jobs. It was an appealing message in a country hamstrung by dynastic politics, corruption and a stalling economy. “He’s a non-politician politician, so he appeals to people who are normally not drawn into politics – a huge constituency,” says Karachi-based writer Mohammed Hanif. “His message is a mixture of defiance to the traditional power elite and reminders of his glamorous past. Being his follower is like hanging out with a celebrity who lectures you on the meaning of life.”During his years in politics, Khan moved away from his womanising past and publicly embraced Islam, to the extent that his critics found a new nickname: “Taliban Khan”. (Among other things, he advocated for negotiations with the Pakistani Taliban, responsible for tens of thousands of deaths in the country, and opposed a series of women’s rights bills.)Some commentators in Pakistan have noted that Khan’s three marriages illustrate that move towards conservatism. In 2004, he and Jemima Goldsmith announced their orce during the nine-year marriage, they had had two sons, Sulaiman Isa and Kasim. (An earlier relationship with heiress Sita White resulted in a daughter, Tyrian.) In 2015, he announced his marriage to British-Pakistani newsreader Reham Khan. The marriage ended acrimoniously the following year. And in 2018, six months before the election that year, Khan married his spiritual healer and mentor Bushra Bibi. She wears a full face-veil, and Khan told reporters that he had never seen her face before their marriage. Yet alongside this shift, and his rousing public criticisms of the west, Khan continued to stay with the Goldsmiths at their west London home on his regular trips to the UK, where his two sons still live.This transformation – from sex symbol to pious Muslim – is just one of many for this political shapeshifter. “He switches between selves as one would switch between languages,” says Taseer. “He never sought inner cohesion. He treated the West as nothing but the source of debased worldly pleasures, in which he occasionally partook, and turned the East into an unassailable beacon of piety. Since neither picture is completely true, it produced an almost willful schizophrenia in him. He lived out his contradictions, but never acknowledged them.”In the 2018 election, the PTI won a wafer-thin majority and Khan became prime minister. The military has ruled Pakistan for roughly half of its 75 years, and even during periods of civilian government, it plays an outsize role in public life. In opposition, Khan criticised the generals for meddling in politics, but his victory in 2018 was attributed broadly to military patronage, and during his tenure the army expanded its role in government. It was another transformation, this time from avowed political outsider to military favourite.Although the victory was the culmination of two decades of political struggle, Khan’s performance in government was lacklustre, characterised by policy U-turns and a worsening climate of partisanship and censorship in which scores of journalists and political activists were jailed. “He never stopped being an opposition leader when he became prime minister. He refused to reach across the aisle,” says Kugelman. “He didn’t make compromises and concessions. Instead, he used maximalist rhetoric and labelled his rivals and those that disagreed with him as traitors and thieves. He injected more toxicity into a political environment already heavy with the poison of polarisation.”Pakistan is mired in an economic crisis inherited from the previous government and exacerbated by global issues such as rising energy costs and supply-chain problems. Although the problems are not entirely of Khan’s making, his handling of the economy has been chaotic, losing him public support. Additionally, his relationship with the all-powerful military soured last year after a dispute over the appointment of the next spy chief. Sensing a window of opportunity, opposition parties united to call a vote of no-confidence.Khan’s ousting puts him in good company: in the tumultuous context of Pakistan, no prime minister has ever completed their term. And it is clear that Khan plans to fight on. On Sunday, in his first comments since losing the vote, Khan tweeted: “Pakistan became an independent state in 1947, but the freedom struggle begins again today against a foreign conspiracy of regime change. It is always the people of the country who defend their sovereignty and democracy.”This might be a hint of things to come, as Pakistan gears up for a general election next year. “He will keep up the narrative that he was ousted by a US-sponsored plot, in order to energise his base and attract broader swathes of support from a public that can be reflexively suspicious of US policy,” says Kugelman. “Khan will not be disappearing quietly into the night. That’s not his personal style and it’s not his brand of politics.”Samira Shackle is author of Karachi Vice. title: river oxford becomes second england achieve bathing water status
story: A stretch of the Thames will become the second designated river bathing spot in England after record levels of support. The Wolvercote Mill Stream in north Oxford will be regularly monitored for harmful bacterial levels during the swimming season between May and September. The decision came after a campaign by locals who want the monitoring to lead to cleaner water at the spot. The consultation had 1,267 responses, with just seven not in favour of designating the site, a record level. The river has an average of 46 swimmers a day during the peak season, but tests have found levels of e-coli bacteria exceeding the threshold level for safe bathing water quality.The designation does not guarantee clean water, but is expected to put pressure on Thames Water and local landowners to stop pollutants entering the area and will enable locals to know when it is safe to swim. A 2021 study of local river water quality found no stretch of water in Oxford would be classified as fit for bathing, with the main cause being raw sewage overflows. Raw sewage was discharged for over 1,500 hours from five overflow locations in Oxford, according to data from the Environment Agency. England has only one other river with designated bathing status, a stretch of the River Wharfe at Ilkley, West Yorkshire, which was rated “poor” for water quality after tests in January found evidence of human and animal bacteria. Claire Robertson, Oxford Rivers Project Officer at Thames21, said: “I’m overjoyed this designation is going ahead. This stretch of river is a regularly used and treasured place for hundreds of people - families, swimmers, kayakers, rowers, anglers, birdwatchers - and a home for many other creatures, and this is the very least it deserves.“I’m looking forward to working locally with Thames Water and other partners to ensure the water quality improves, and nationally to help other groups protect their local rivers.”The East Cowes Esplanade on the Isle of Wight will be added to the list of designated bathing spots, which includes coastal waters. MPs have called for water companies to ensure that at least one stretch of river in each of their areas is monitored by 2025.Polling for The  earlier this year found that more than 80 per cent of people expect to be able to safely swim in a local river, despite officials from the Environment Agency insisting they are not intended for human use.“While bathing water quality has improved in recent years and England now has the cleanest bathing waters since records began, we know that water quality at these sites won’t change overnight. “It will take time and all those with a role to play must commit to achieve the necessary improvements,” said Rebecca Pow, Environment Minister.“We are continuing to drive up the quality of lakes, rivers and seas for the public to enjoy through the measures in our Environment Act, and I would encourage more applications for popular bathing areas, both inland and coastal, that may also be suitable for designation.”More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Vladimir Putin vows ‘clear and noble’ aims of news politics -questions-rishi-sunak-must-"Rishi Sunak faces a whole list of concerns amid tax rowByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsCrisis-hit Rishi Sunak will undergo an investigation by the Prime Ministeraposs sleaze watchdog as he battles to save his political career. Downing Street confirmed that Boris Johnson had ordered his ethics adviser Lord Geidt to probe the Chancelloraposs conduct after a request from Mr Sunak himself.Mr Sunakaposs family finances have been in the spotlight after it emerged that his we Akshata Murty had non-domicile tax status, allowing her to legally avoid paying UK taxes on overseas income. She U-turned on Friday to save her husbandaposs job by vowing to pay UK tax on herforeign income, which includes an estimated £. million-a-year in shares from the Indian IT giant Infosys - founded by her billionaire father Narayana Murty. Mr Sunak attempted to defuse the row by asking Lord Geidt to investigate, as he said he was confident he had declared everything properly. The Prime Ministeraposs deputy spokeswoman said: Iaposm not aware of whether Lord Geidt himself has begun his work. But I can confirm that the Prime Minister has agreed to the request from the Chancellor for Lord Geidt to undertake this work. Here are some of the questions the Chancellor needs to clear up. How much has his we saved in UK tax through non-dom status  Mr Sunakaposs nightmare week began when it emerged that his we held non-dom status, potentially saving her millions of pounds in tax. The arrangement, which is legal, allows people who are domiciled abroad to avoid paying UK tax on their overseas income. Her spokeswoman initially tried to claim it was because she was an Indian citizen but she then admitted that Ms Murty paid the British Government £,-a-year to keep the status.Ms Murty was forced to into a U-turn on Friday and said she would now pay UK tax on her foreign income. This includes a .% stake in Indian IT giant Infosys, founded by her billionaire father Naranya Murty. Her share is worth an estimated £ million and provides around £. million in idends per year. Under non-dom rules, Ms Murty was not obliged to pay UK tax on this income - and it is unclear how big her tax bill could have been.The BBC estimated she would have saved £. million in UK tax based on these figures.Ms Murty remains domiciled in India where she eventually wants to . What did Rishi Sunak declare about it  Mr Sunak is understood to have declared his weaposs tax status to the Cabinet Office when he first became a minister in . Sources said the Treasury was also aware, so as to manage any potential conflicts of interest. However, what happened after he made the declaration is not clear, because her status is not on his public declaration of ministerial interests.  Mr Sunak has asked for Lord Geidt to review all his declarations of interest since he became a minister in  to ensure they had been properly stated. He said he was confident he had acted appropriately at all times, but his overriding concern was that the public should have confidence in the answers. Guidance to ministers says the list is not an account of all the interests or financial arrangements held by a Minister or members of their close family, adding: Rather it is a list of any such interests, which are, or might reasonably be perceived to be, directly relevant to that particular minister’s public duties. Why did he hold a US green card until last year  Mr Sunak confirmed on Friday that he held a US green card for more than a year while he was Chancellor. A spokeswoman said he sought guidance ahead of his first US trip in a Government capacity in October - despite taking on the top Treasury job in February . People with green cards are treated as lawful permanent residents by US tax authorities, and it is seen as a step towards full citizenship.  Mr Sunakaposs spokeswoman said he filed US tax s, but specically as a non-resident, in full compliance with the law. The Sunaks met at Stanford University and worked in the US before moving to the UK to pursue Mr Sunakaposs political career. They are understood to have a holiday home in Calornia.At a Downing Street press conference, Boris Johnson said he was unaware of Mr Sunak holding a US green card, but stressed that the Chancellor had done absolutely everything he was required to do. Is he a beneficiary in tax havens  The Independent reported on Friday that Mr Sunak was listed as the beneficiary of trusts set up in the British Virgin Islands and Cayman Islands to help manage the tax and business affairs of Ms Murtyaposs family interests. But a spokeswoman close to the Sunak family said: No-one in Akshataaposs family is aware of this alleged trust. Labour called on Mr Sunak to explain the situation.Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves said: We need full disclosure now. Has he broken the ministerial code  Labour has accused the Chancellor of breaking the ministerial code, the set of guidelines that top politicians must follow.It states that outside interests must be reported to the Permanent Secretary of their department. It is understood Mr Sunak did report his weaposs status to the Cabinet Office and the Treasury was also aware. The ministerial code says the register of interests should also cover interests of the ministeraposs spouse or partner and close family which might be thought to give rise to a conflict. Lord Geidt will examine this as part of his investigation. Politicians who break the ministerial code are traditionally expected to resign. story: Fishy Rishi is a beached Chancellor struggling to survive and considering quittingChancellor Rishi Sunak seems unlikely to ever succeed the morally corrupt incumbent Prime Minister Boris Johnson - all down to the ongoing non-dom scandal related to his we, Kevin Maguire says" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _The-Prince-Of-Wales-And-Duchess-Of-Cornwall-Celebrate-The-British-Asian-Trust.jpg" width"" "" The Tory minister and his billionaire heiress we Akshata Murthy were the victims of a smear campaign this week Image: UK Press via Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Apr |commentsFish rot from the head down and the stench of contempt in Downing Street is seeing scales falling from voters’ eyes. The nets trawling the sordid financial affairs of his incredibly wealthy family may yet produce another jaw-dropper that will force the Tory moneybags to resign in disgrace. And the morally corrupt Prime Minister he’s now unlikely ever to succeed – charlatan Boris Johnson, who presided over widespread law-breaking during Covid, his head on the chopping block until Putin spared him – remains a rotten man. Draw a Venn diagram and the fools spouting drivel to shield slippery Sunak and an heiress we, Akshata Murty, who’d pay £, to avoid millions of pounds in British tax, overlap with idiots who ly claimed Johnson didn’t hold parties and is innocent of all charges. title: oscars now open accusations double
story: Oscars are now open to accusations of double standards over Will Smith slap responseDarren Lewis says consistency is clearly lacking in the wake of Will Smith slapping Chris Rock on stage at the Oscars - sexual predators Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski still have theirs awardsWill Smith and we Jada Pinkett Smith at the  Vanity Fair Oscars Party after he slapped Chris Rock Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDarren Lewis:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsIn their rush to be seen to be doing something about Will Smith, the Oscars board of governors ended up doing nothing more than leaving themselves open to accusations of double standards.They couldn’t take away Will Smith’s Best Actor Oscar for slapping Chris Rock when sexual predators Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski still have theirs.They couldn’t expel Men In Black star Smith because he’d moved far more quickly to take control of the story and resign from the Academy.So they banned him from all their events, including the Oscars, for  years. Fair enough. We are all agreed that you can’t go around slapping people, even though this column remains of the opinion that we are in a weird place with so-called comedians at awards nights: Dead set against violence but prepared to normalise the kind of bullying and humiliation of iniduals at these types of events that would probably earn you a trip to HR in the workplace. Again, shame on Rock who made Smith’s we Jada the butt of his jokes because of her shaven head. It is well known she suffers from alopecia. Would she have been fair gameshe’d had breast cancer  Reading Smith’s autobiography on holiday last week , I was also struck by this in the second chapter. “When I was nine years old, I watched my father punch my mother in the side of her head so hard that she collapsed. I saw her spit blood. That moment in that bedroom, probably more than any other in my le, has defined who I am today. “Within everything that I have done since then – the awards, the accolades, the spotlights and the attention, the characters and the laughs – there has been a subtle string of apologies to my mother for my inaction that day. “For failing her in that moment. For failing to stand up to my father. For being a coward.” None of that excuses his actions two weeks ago. But it does explain why he snapped on that night. His book also details a string of examples he would come to recognise as double standards in his negative treatment over the years. A furious debate is understood to have raged within the Academy’s , members in Whats App groups in the fortnight after Smith’s slap.It would be fascinating to see a Venn diagram of which members were dead set on Smith’s suspension and which ones signed a  petition calling for Polanski – who admitted raping a child four decades ago – to be released from detention in Zurich.It took  years for the Academy to take a stand over Polanski, only expelling him in . Before then he’d won a Best Director Oscar in  to a standing ovation. No statement from the Academy back then blasting his “unacceptable” and “harmful” conduct, as there was last week over Smith. Allegations over the conduct of a string of other big names, including Kevin Spacey, Woody Allen and Mel Gibson have not seen any of them exiled over the last few decades either, even temporarily. But consistency doesn’t appear to be paramount in the minds of the Academy or its members – only appeasing the social media mob. I want them to be reassured that me and the Government are on their side and doing what we can to ease the burdens that we are facing. Yet aides have briefed that Mr Sunak ordered an aggressive Whitehall inquiry into how his weaposs tax details were leaked, rather than focusing on the cost of living crisis. news politics tory-k-says-im-worried-"James Heappey says he’s ‘worried about his overdraft’ByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA top Tory earning £k after a pay rise has complained he’s “worried about my overdraft” - while Brits suffer the biggest drop in pay in nine years. Experts said cost of living crisis had “set in” as official figures showed regular pay tumbled .% in the three months to February, after CPI inflation. The same figure but month-to-month to February shows a drop of .%, the biggest since August , according to the Office for National Statistics . The Resolution Foundation warned there was a gulf between the public sector, where pay fell .% in real terms, and the private sector where it fell only .%. And today even Armed Forces Minister James Heappey said he was feeling the pinch - despite a pay rise on April  taking his salary to £, a year.Askedhe would publish his tax , as people are calling for Chancellor Rishi Sunak to do, he told LBC Radio: “I’ve got to be honest, my finances are pretty uncomplicated.“And like lots of people, by the th of the month, Iaposm pretty worried about my overdraft, rather than any sort of amazing tax [inaudible].”It comes days after another Tory minister on £k, Kit Malthouse, said the rise in energy prices was hitting him “very signicantly”.  Mr Heappey added despite his taxbeing very simple, he would resist calls to publish them because “I actually think MPs should be entitled to a degree of privacy.” Mr Heappey spoke less than an hour after the ONS published updated figures on weekly earnings falling behind inflation. According to the CPIH measure of inflation, preferred by the ONS, real regular pay excluding bonuses dropped % in the year to the three months ending in February. One a one month basis, the same calculation shows real regular pay dropping .% in the year to February. The same figures using CPI inflation were .% and .%. While pay rose % in the quarter, it was far outstripped by inflation. And experts warn the cost-of-living crisis will get worse as inflation is set to peak near % later this year. Chancellor Rishi Sunak said the Government was helping to cushion the impacts of global price rises through over £ billion of support for the cost of living this financial year. But business groups said households and companies were already coming under strain from eye-watering price hikes. Pat McFadden, Labouraposs shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, said: Rishi Sunak could have chosen a one-off windfall tax on huge oil and gas company profits to cut household energy bills by up to £.  Instead, heaposs decided to make Britain the only major economy to land working people with higher taxes in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis. Darren Morgan, director of economic statistics at the ONS, warned: “While strong bonuses continue to mitigate the effects of rising prices on peopleaposs total earnings, basic pay is now falling noticeably in real terms. The latest ONS labour market data also revealed the unemployment rate fell further below levels seen before the pandemic struck, at .% in the three months to February, which is the lowest reading since December  and down from .% in the previous three-month period. There were , fewer jobless Britons at . million in the quarter to February, while those in employment rose , to . million. But the Resolution Foundation warned: “A buoyant labour market is not generating much wage pressure, especially once base effects from furlough are taken into account. “And with inflation soaring, Britain’s pay squeeze will continue to tighten. “The current fall in real wages is not projected to end until late , and will leave average wages no higher than in .” TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady called for an emergency Budget from Chancellor Rishi Sunak.She said: “Everyone should have the security to be able to pay their bills. But household incomes are being obliterated as wages fail to keep pace with the spiralling cost of living. “We can’t go on like this… Rising hardship is a political choice. Fuming mum-of-three Joanne Black says she gave her £, gown to Alterations by Janice in Paisley, Scotland, at the beginning of March to have the shoulders of the frock lted and the sleeves taken up.But the -year-old told the Daily Record she was less than impressed when, five weeks later, she picked up her dress only to find that none of the adjustments had been made.The mum, who said the dress was in a garment bag when she collected it, claims she was disgusted to find it covered in dog hair, dirt and dust asit had been dragged along the ground. Joanne, who is due to tie the knot with her partner of three years, Tony, in Auchen Castle in Moffat on May , says the experience has robbed her of all her excitement in the run-up to her special day.She told the Record: Iaposve been so stressed. I didnapost sleep the night I got it back and I was crying. Itaposs stressful enough organising a wedding, but this has really put me off my dress. On one part of the sleeve, you can literally pull the fabric and see itaposs just falling away. story: Britains third-largest baby born weighing more than a stone - and he loves porridgeFive-month-old Alpha Stone Mitchell, is as big as his older sister Twyla-Bay, who is almost one and a half - his mum says his massive growth is thanks to chomping down breakfasts of porridgeCherral said her bump was huge but she never expected Alpha would be so large Image: Cherral Mitchell   SWNSByJoe Smith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A baby crowned Britainaposs third-largest newborn was delivered weighing more than a stone and is already the same size as his -month-old sister.Five-month-old Alpha Stone Mitchell, is as big as his older sister Twyla-Bay, who is almost one and a half. His mum says his massive growth is thanks to his hearty breakfasts of porridge. Alpha was born via C-section on October  last year, weighing in at a chunky lbs oz, making him Britainaposs third largest newborn.Despite not yet being six months old, big boy Alpha - who now weighs st lbs, is already wearing clothing designed for nine to -month-olds. Mum Cherral Mitchell, , told the Sun she has had to wean her hungry little man off milk.Now Alpha loves to chow down on porridge and rusk biscuits, even though most babies donapost do so until at least  weeks. Cherral said: We knew he was going to be a big boy as my bump was huge, but we didnapost realise quite how big he would be until he was here. Iaposd had three babies before and with Alpha it felt like we skipped the newborn stage altogether and went straight to him being three months old.” People often mistake Alpha and his sister Twyla-Bay for twins, despite her being more than three times his age, Cherral said, because Alpha is already almost the same height as her.Alpha starts the day with baby porridge, followed by a oz bottle of baby milk every three hours and a baby rusk biscuit in the evening. Cherral who is also mum to Rouge-Angel, five, Lyon, three, and Twyla-Bay, one, with electrical engineer husband Tyson, , said none of her other children were anywhere near Alpha’s size at the same age. When he was born at John Radclfe Hospital in  Cherral and Tyson were shocked at his size, despite doctors’ predictions that their baby would be a whopper. Tyson even had to go home to bring back some three to six-month clothes for him.” Hospital staff measured Alpha and began to google records for the largest babies born in the UK right there in the delivery room. They excitedly informed Cherral that her newborn was the third-largest in the UK. story: Brits caught out by airport Covid restrictions forced to pay more to board flightsMany people flying abroad this Easter are having to pay for last-minute Covid tests and risk missing their flights as they hadnt realised some countries still require certicationHuge numbers of travellers are having to pay for last minute tests and risk missing their flight Image: REX ShutterstockBySara Odeen-Isbister:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsThousands of Brit travellers have turned up at UK airports during the Easter holidays only to be caught out by the latest travel rules. Sunseeking Brits looking to head overseas for a much-needed break are being warned to plan ahead as thousands are rocking up without the Covid certication they need to get to their destination.In Britain, the Government has scrapped all of its previous travel rules from Covid tests to qurantine periods, while other countries have also begun to lt their restrictions. France recently reopened to unvaccinated Brits for holidays, with no quarantine requirements, while anyone aged  or over can visit Spain provided they are either fully vaccinated against Covid, or can show proof of recent recovery.However, the rules are dferent for each country and the many still have restrictions in place, as holidaymakers are finding out to their dismay.  Many still require a negative test result - something a number of Brit travellers appear not to realise. Not only have they had to pay up to £ for last minute testing, passengers have risked missing their flight as they wait in long queues at airports that are already under strain due to staff shortages and a particularly busy Easter period.Nick Markham, co-founder of Cignpost ExpressTest, who offer Covid testing at a number of UK airports, told Travel Weekly that Brit holidaymakers were turning up weithout the correct Covid test certication for their intended destination.He said: “Because the UK government has lted all Covid restrictions, people naturally assume that all testing everywhere has ended.  “However, many countries still have some level of Covid testing in place for arrivals. They include the US, which requires all travellers to take a negative Covid test no more than  hours before they fly, and most of Europe’s short haul destinations, which have testing rules for arrivals who are not fully vaccinated, often including children aged  and over.” If you want to travel to the United States, you must provide a negative Covid test  hours before flying. While many European holiday destinations require children who are not fully vaccinatred to provide negative Covid tests to prove they are not carrying the bug.  And Brits could be stung in the wallet, with last-minute, unplanned Covid tests reportedly ranging in price from £ to as much as £results are needed urgently in a few hours. And travellers still risk missing flights waiting for results to come back or stuck waiting in long queues to do their tests.Speaking to the Sun, Mr Markham added: Airports are already under pressure with staff shortages often themselves caused by COVID infections. That could mean longer queues at check-ins or for essential purchases at the airport.So having to queue for a last-minute test and then hoping the result comes through in time could leave travellers without time to clear security and catch their flight. story: Exclusive: Couple sleep in coats and cant imagine using heating again as energy bills doubleGerald Porter, , and we Mair Porter, , from Melksham, Wiltshire, say they won’t be using the central heating again after their energy bills more than doubled and they now rely on hot water bottles and fleece jackets to stay warmGerald Porter and we Mair have stopped donating to charities as he can no longer afford it Image: MARC GIDDINGSByZahra Khaliq:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments An elderly couple are being forced to wear coats to bed as they can no longer afford their heating bills since they more than doubled last month, saying the increase has “taken over their lives”.Gerald Porter, , is even debating going back to work to get more money to support his we Mair, , who has just been diagnosed with dementia. The couple, who live in Melksham, Wiltshire, have been forced to give up their social lives as cash is so tight and have even stopped using their oven to keep bills down. Gerald served in the Royal Air Force for  years and feels the country he devoted his le to is letting him down. He tells The Mirror: “I don’t want to complain really because I‘ve had a good le, but it comes as a huge disappointment.In the quiet hours when you sit and think, well we did all that and we’ve ended up with all this worry. You’re sort of living on the edge really. “I don’t knowit’s a matter of age but you think, what did we do all that for  Le has changed completely. Before, we would go out lunching and that sort of thing, meeting friends - but we don’t do that anymore. We can’t afford it, every penny has got to be watched. For years, I’ve contributed to causes like the Salvation Army or UNICEF. I give them maybe £ or £ a month - not much - but that’s all stopped. I just can’t afford it. It grieves me to do it, but there you go, I just can’t do anything about it.” Since their bills jumped from £ to £, Gerald and Mair have started setting strict budgets for their daily gas and electricity usage, which means giving up the use of their central heating altogether. Gerald has worked out that it costs him p to boil his kettle - a cheaper solution that allows both him and Mair to surround themselves with multiple hot water bottles to stay warm while at home.They’ve also stopped using the oven to keep costs low, relying instead on their microwave. He said: “We’re on a fixed income so there’s nothing we can do about it. I can put it on and go into debt but I just want somebody to do something. “I can’t imagine a time that I can turn the heating on again, there’s nothing in sight and there’s nothing  I can do” “The dference between £ and £ - it’s a chasm that I can’t cross. I’m not putting the heating on because I refuse to go into into debt.” Gerald added: At night, we cover the bed in coats and use an extra blanket because Mair is particularly susceptible to the cold. We wear coats indoors now. They’re like long jackets lined with synthetic wool. We’re having to use those in bed too just to make sure we keep warm. As you get older, the extremes of heat and cold affect you more. “We’ve got an Aga, but we have no plans to use that. Putting it on would be absolutely catastrophic. We just use it for storage - it’s just a nice piece of furniture now, nothing .And yet this isnapost the only dficulty that the couple are facing, as the cost increase came shortly after -year-old Mair was diagnosed with vascular dementia. Gerald added:I’m trying to take it in my stride. It’s unavoidable, but just another thing to worry about really. Iaposm afraid with my weaposs illness, they sort of retreat within themselves. She doesnapost have opinions now. She has very basic feelings like aposI’m too coldapos or aposI’m too hot.aposGerald went viral on Twitter last month after sharing a message about how the price hikes are impacting their lives. He said: “Our heating is the biggest expense we’ve got. We live on very average pensions, and the reason why I put the tweet out wasnapost an appeal for help or anything, it was anger. I was so angry. When I worked the figures out I thought, my God, what am I doing  I had loads of people come back to me and say, aposweaposll give you some moneyapos. I even had a young woman say, Iaposm a single mum but Iaposve got some money put away and you’re welcome to half of it. He added: From a large point of view, there is help. I’ve also got my family. Youaposre a telephone away from homeyou need anybody. My granddaughter is wonderful. I couldnapost manage without it. Iaposm very lucky. It’d cover bills full stop, says Gerald. But Gerald believes that he shouldnapost have to rely on others to support him financially, and that the government should be held responsible for the effects that the cost of living crisis are having on regular people like himself.  I detest the thought of relying on benefits. The kindness of strangers. I really hate that. People are generous. I know that from the tweet. That really surprised me. But itaposs just the thought that you are really are an inidual. Now youaposre on your own. Youaposve got to get over it and thereaposs nothing I can do, except sell stuff. Thataposs what I could do. The pair have acknowledged that while the cost of living crisis has forced them to live frugally, they could have been much worse off. story: Mum sick to her stomach after horror crash video that killed daughter shared onlinePaige Rice, , was a passenger in an Audi S when it crashed head on into a Mercedes taxi inside the Queensway Tunnel, in the early hours of Sunday, October  last yearInstagram influencer Paige Rice, , died in hospital after the horror crash in October last year Image: BPM MediaByCharlotte HadfieldRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A grieving mum has issued a heartfelt plea to the thoughtless people sharing a video of a horror crash that killed her beautul baby girl on social media. Paige Rice, , was a passenger in an Audi S when it was involved in a fatal smash with a a Mercedes taxi in the Queensway Tunnel in October last year.Her ex-partner Callum Miller, , a labourer from Stockport, was clocking speeds of mph as he drove the Audi through the tunnel - which connects Liverpool and Birkenhead.An inquest into their deaths, held at Gerard Majella Courthouse in Kirkdale on January , heard Merseyside Police initially launched a criminal investigation into a potential offence of causing death by dangerous driving.But the probe was dropped when it became clear Callum would not survive.Dashcam footage of the crash, which also left the taxi driver with le-changing injuries to his leg and hip, has now emerged on social media, the Liverpool Echo reports. Clare Rice, Paigeaposs mum said she has not been able sleep since finding out that the video was circulating online as she asked people to remove any posts containing the footage. Ms Rice wrote: Yesterday, I found out there’s a video circulating on social media, a video of the crash that killed my daughter. Now I have no idea who has this video and how it’s got online but I want you to know, I’ve not slept since and I feel sick to the stomach. After we lost Paige I was askedI wanted to view the footage, I chose not to for my own sanity. When you grieve someone who’s died and in such a tragic way, Your mind chooses what to think about and what to block out.Finding out the video was online has been really triggering for me, moments which I’d been blocking out to survive my days were now at the forefront of my mind. Why would you want to watch my daughteraposs last moments  I’m heartbroken, the thought of strangers, people who don’t know Paige or me watching something so traumatic and distressing. When people post such personal pictures or videos without consent, it can have a serious impact on people’s lives. Ms Rice said her le has been turned upside down by the death of her daughter as she shared a series of photos of herself with Paige growing up. She continued: I’m still Paige’s mum and I still have that protective instinct. I know Paige would hate that this video is online. Look at these pictures, this is my beautul baby girl Paige.  She was taken from us in October, only  years old. No matter how old your child gets, they’re still our babies. I had Paige at a young age and it’s Pretty much always been us three. My le has revolved around my children and making sure they never went without. I can’t tell you how much my le has been turned upside down since loosing my daughter. When you lose a child, just getting through an hour is an accomplishment.  The last five months has been a blur when it comes to time and I don’t know how I’m surviving each day with this heartache, a pain you will never know, unless you’ve lived it. To cause added stress and upset is disrespectful and thoughtless. My le will never be the same again. I’ve lost my daughter and my friend and my son has lost his sister and we’ve all lost a massive piece of our lives. Paige left behind many broken hearts, she is loved and now missed by so many people, someone’s daughter, sister, granddaughter, niece, cousin and friend. We don’t deserve any more upset. I hope the posts are removed, I’d be extremely thankful. story: National Offer Day - when are primary school places announced For parents in many parts of the country, National Offer Day is just around the corner and will give them an increasingly clear idea about what the future holds for their childs next stepsChildren will find out which primary school theyre going to next week Image: Getty ImagesByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsParents in the UK are about to get the news about which primary school their kids are going to be attending. Known as National Offer Day, anxious s will find out whether their kids will be heading to their preferred school in September.Parts of the UK have dferent offer days, so be sure you know exactly which date applies to you and your children. The application process also ies from place to place, meaning there is no one-size-fits-all system to get your head around. Details including dates can also y between some councils. As the big day approaches here’s what you need to know. When are National Offer Days for primary schools  In Wales, National Offer Day is April . This year that falls on a Tuesday. Parents will have until Wednesday, May   to officially accept or reject the offer made to their child. Meanwhile, in England, letters are due to be sent out by local councils to parents and s on Monday, April , a deviation from the usual send-out day of April . This is because April  is a Saturday and so they are sent out on the next working day. In Northern Ireland, parents can expect to find out about their options on Thursday, April . This will be done through an online portal where notications of P applications will be found. In Scotland no offers will be made, as local councils decide which school your child goes to rather than parents having the main say. You can make a requestyou are unhappy with the school your child is sent to, however success will be dependent on available places. How are primary school offers made   Across the UK, most applications close in January. For Wales, the  deadline passed on January  with applications made online. Gov.uk has developed a navigation system online that allows parents to place their applications at their chosen school. In England, applications are made to the local council, evenyou are applying for a school in a dferent council area. Applications can be made online or via a paper form with s asked to list the schools they would like to send their kids to in order of preference. However, it is important to check exactly when application open days are held as they are dferent for each local council. All applications closed on January . You will need to apply before your child can start school either when they are three years old or recently turned four. In Northern Ireland, you can apply for your child’s P place online, with application portals closed at pm on January  . Meanwhile, in Scotland, some councils will send a letter to confirm your child has a place the year before they go to school. In those councils that don’t, you will need to enrol them the year before they’re due to start. Trick for shoes As the staff member in charge of the Queenaposs wardrobe, Angela revealed in her book many handy tips and tricks she uses when it comes to looking after Her Majestyaposs clothes, accessories and jewellery.Before the book was released, it had long been reported that Her Majesty employs an assistant to wear in her shoes. So how did she get the colour of the gown just right  Yorkshire Tea. In her book, Angela wrote: She writes: Together, we sourced lace to complement that being made in Italy, and to make sure it looks authentic we dyed it in Yorkshire tea . We placed each piece of lace in a small bowl, from the Dressersapos kitchen, filled with cool water and a tea bag, and left it for about five minutes, checking regularly until the colour was perfect. The gown has since been worn by the likes of Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Harry and Meghanaposs son Archie. story: Woman born with vocal chord paralysis forced to quit job and cant visit pubClaudia Serra, who lives in Croydon, London, has left vocal cord paralysis, which means that she struggles to be heard - with her voice described as breathy, quiet and weakClaudia Serra, who lives in Croydon, has left vocal cord paralysis, which means that she struggles to be heard Image: Claudia SerraByEmma MagnusCharlie Duffield:,  Apr |commentsA woman says she has been forced to quit her job and avoid loud environments as a result of her extremely rare condition. Growing up in Italy, Claudia Serra knew something was dferent about her voice. She realised that she couldnapost scream in the playground like other children and singing in school plays was hard as well.Even just talking in a noisy environment or with a group was exhausting,My London reports. When Claudia was , she decided to see a doctor, and was diagnosed with left vocal cord paralysis, a rare condition which causes the voice to sound breathy, quiet and weak, and can affect the breathing.If both cords are affected, the voice can disappear altogether.In Claudiaaposs case, the condition was caused at birth as she was been born prematurely at just six months old. The -year-old said: Despite the pathology, it was a relief to know what was happening. It was the answer I had been waiting for for a long time, especially in adolescence...I was ready to do what I could to find my voice. Once she had finished school, Claudia started speech therapy, which aimed to move the working cord towards the paralysed one. After nine months of twice-weekly sessions and daily breathing and vocal exercises, she found out that, despite some nodules on her vocal cords being removed, her voice still sounded the same.In , Claudia opted for a surgical intervention, known as an Injection Laryngoplasty. The surgery works by injecting fat into the vocal cords to increase their volume - and means that Claudia lost her voice entirely for a week, communicating with a pen and paper. When it re-emerged, it had increased in strength - but only temporarily. The following year, Claudia says she re-attempted the same surgery, only to find that the results were similar: a brief period of improvement, before her voice ed to its previous state. For the next six years, Claudia tried dferent forms of speech therapy, to little success.  Eventually, she says her doctors in Italy told her that there was nothing more that they could do for her. She said: This brought me a lot of sadness...I have never been able to enjoy a nice evening in the pub, or go out for dinner with a group because it is dficult to be heard in noisy environments. Otherwise at the end of the day, vocal fatigue assaults you and you no longer want to talk to anyone. A vocal problem affects everyday le. Itaposs not just about having a hoarse or lower tone - the voice is a delicate communication tool. [We use it to]communicate, to work, have social relationships and to express our feelings. The voice is the mirror of the soul.In October , having moved to London two years earlier, Claudia had her third surgery: a thyroplasty, where an implant was inserted through the cartilage into her voice box. She was optimistic, and at first pleased with the results. She said: After surgery in November my voice was much louder, as was my laughter and coughing. I had less respiratory fatigue while walking, for example, and in noisier environments it seemed easier to raise my voice and speak. But in December, Claudia felt disappointed again, as her voice began to strain in loud environments. [Itaposs like] I miss the air, asI were climbing a mountain. I have to rest, plus [I have] neck and throat pain. At the time, Claudia says she was working at a dog grooming salon. With the sound of dogs barking, pets being washed and people talking, Claudia says it became dficult for her to communicate - leading to fatigue and severe neck pain - and she left the job. It was a real blow that Claudiaaposs third surgery hadnapost altered her voice. She said: I was hoping that with the last intervention I would finally be able to get my voice, to get more vocal stability, but it didnapost happen. Of course, there are those very dficult and despondent moments, but then I look inside myself and I see that there is still that strength and courage to go on and keep fighting. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Claudia is now waiting to find out whether she will need to undergo a fourth surgery. In terms of her work, she is having a hard time finding a job which will accommodate her needs. She enjoyed her role at the grooming salon, and loves cooking, flowers and photography, but requires a quiet working environment where she does not have to strain or raise her voice. All this has made me a very empathetic, sensitive person who knows how to listen, said Claudia. I would also like to expand my knowledge on the voice - and maybe one day help someone like me.  And, despite her long struggle to be heard, Claudia is finally speaking out: she runs a YouTube channel and Instagram account where she shares her experiences, and intends to write a book about her vocal journey.She said: Despite the ups and downs, these years in search of my voice have given me the strength not to give up. There are many people with dferent vocal problems, who do not feel understood, who feel alone, who do not know how to treat their pathology, or who give up. I want them to know that they are not alone and that they donapost have to give up...I know how hard it can be, but one day you will find your voice! story: Bride bans plus ones from wedding - but guests slam harsh rules and refuse to attendA bride-to-be has banned wedding guests from bringing a plus one, but her rule has caused some invited guests to refuse to attend - as they branded her disrespectfulThe bride is sticking to her strict guest rulesImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Apr |commentsA wedding should be about celebrating the couple that is coming together to tie the knot, and at most ceremonies, invited guests are encouraged to bring their own partners as a plus one so that everyone can get into the romantic spirit.But one bride-to-be on Reddit has banned her guests from bringing anyone  to her wedding unless they fall under strict exceptions set by her and her fiancé - and the rule is causing a ide among her guest list. The woman explained that only people named in the invitations are allowed to attend her wedding day, and said that people will have their partner listed as a guestthey are someone that the bride and groom personally know, would go to dinner with, or would have been invited regardless of their relationship status. In her post, the bride also insisted that her rule even extends to engaged couples and married couples, who will be expected to leave their fiancés and spouses behind for the day.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. She said: Iaposm getting married and like every other bride, I too have certain rules I want for my wedding to go smoothly. One of them is the no plus ones rule. Only people named in the invitation are invited. The criteria I have for people who will get to bring their partners are:Both my fiancé and I know of your partner and have met them. If I know your partner and my fiancé doesnapost, that disqualies them and vice versa. If Iaposd personally go to dinner with you and your partner. If Iaposd invite your partner as a separate person anyway and not just because theyaposre your partner. If your partner is also a friend of mine.Those who meet those criteria get to bring their partners. If they donapost, then they donapost bring them. Simple.  That also excludes long term relationships, engaged couples and married couples as well. We know it might seem harsh but those are the rules weaposve decided to set so we can be more comfortable. It has nothing to do with budget or venue capacity. Purely our choice. After making her rules clear, the woman found that several people on her guest list have chosen to reject the invitation and not attend the wedding - including her cousin, who isnapost allowed to bring his fiancée despite their one-year engagement.
