title: Children learn about water cycle
story: MEMBERS of Northern Ireland Waterrsquos education team paid a recent visit to pupils at Holy Family Primary School in Teconnaught to teach them about the the water cycle.The organisationrsquos lsquoHO and the Wonderful World of Waterrsquo educational programme teaches children all about the cycle, alongside the value of water, the dferent forms it takes and what impact humans have on it.During the visit to Holy Family, children were introduced to H, a waterfigure and mascot for the programme.They learnt how rain water is cleaned and sewage is treated keeping the country healthy before the pupils took part in a lsquobag it and bin itrsquo activity to demonstrate what can and canrsquot be flushed down the toilet.In addition, the Holy Family pupils were introduced to NI Waterrsquos chosen charity ndash WaterAid, which works to help those who have no access to safe water or sanitation.NI Waterrsquos outreach and learning officer, Anna Killen, said the organisation placed great importance on educating young people in the vital role water plays in everyonersquos le.She continued: ldquoHO is a fun way for children to learn about the water cycle, why water is essential for good health and how they can help to conserve this precious resource. ldquoNI Water are s of the infrastructure, the networks and assets, but every one of us uses the service. Only together, as a company and a community, can we continue to protect our most valuable and precious asset ndash water.Anna said the education team was delighted with the positive feedback it has received from schools, including Holy Family, which participated in NI Waterrsquos educational programme.She added: ldquoItrsquos a fantastic way for us to deliver what matters for the local community and educate future generations of water users.The NI Water programme is aimed at Key Stage  pupils and and is designed to complement the lsquoWorld Around Usrsquo, a key element of the Northern Ireland Primary Curriculum..prettyPhoto

title: David Cross Foundation in £5k boost for Columban Way walk
story: PLANS to develop local walking routes which will be part of an international tourist attraction have secured a pound, boost.The David Cross Foundation has weighed in with it support to develop the Columban Way linking Dundrum with Comber.The Columban Way is a pilgrim route that follows the footsteps of Columbanus through eight European countries, with the Friends of Columbanus Bangor delighted with the financial boost from the local Foundation.Group chairwoman, Deborah Girvan, said the final stage of the Columban Way was launched by Ards and North Down Council last October from Comber to Bangor via Newtownards, the Clandeboye Estate and Helenrsquos Bay.ldquoTo realise this ambitious project, members of Friends of Columbanus Bangor have been exploring possible walking routes that are safe andtraffic free, which will join up the route from Dundrum to Comber, she explained.ldquoWe approached the David Cross Foundation for a grant to enable us to map the route, identy pinch points and barriers and produce a financial analysis as to how much it would cost to develop this part of the route.Mrs Girvan explained that once the feasibility study is completed, the findings will be presented to local councils, including Newry, Mourne and Down, to encourage them to develop the Columban Way in their respective areas.ldquoWe are delighted and extremely grateful to the David Cross Foundation for their generosity in helping us to achieve our objectives, she added.Downpatrick area councillor, Cadogan Enright, believes the Columban Way has the potential to be developed along the old railway line from Dundrum to Downpatrick and then follow the original path of the Ulster Way along the Quoile River, which was developed by Wilfred Capper in the late s. ldquoI have been working on opening up walking routes in the Lecale district for years, he continued.ldquoI am very excited about the possibility of a scenic, walking route that will be linked to the European Columban Way. By working in partnership with Ards and North Down and Newry, Mourne and Down councils, we have an opportunity to develop a sustainable, international walking route, which has the potential to attract visitors, both from home and abroad, to explore our outstanding countryside and learn about our incredible Christian Heritage.Cllr Enright believes that developing a trail of this scale will also encourage walkers to visit existing tourist attractions such as the Livingston Centre at Killinchy Parish Church and stop off on the way in restaurants and stay in local accommodation which in turn will bring much needed income and business to the local economy.Hinch Distillery owner, Dr Terry Cross mdash who set up the David Cross Foundation in memory of his son mdash said he was very impressed with the application for funding from Friends of Columbanus Bangor.ldquoThis project has the ability to bring people from all walks of le to meet and greet one another, regardless of their community background, he enthused.ldquoBuilding relationships, peace and reconciliation across Europe is now more important than ever given the critical situation that has erupted in Ukraine. I wish them every success with their proposal to develop a walking route, which will bring much pleasure to local and international visitors. .prettyPhoto

title: Down High star in event
story: ST Patrickrsquos Day is always a special occasion in the sporting calendar and this year thankfully events at The Meadows Equestrian Centre were back to normal.The annual inter-school showjumping competition attracted teams from across the province, and the open class, which was a qualier for Balmoral Show was particularly competitive.In the novice class, Sarah Carse, Emily Carse, Ellen MacNabb and Sophie Herron were narrowly beaten into second place.In the open class, Down High had been drawn th in the competition, and just before they entered the arena, only one other school had finished the course on a zero score.The spectator grandstand was full, the weather was close to perfect and the fences were set to be executed with precision.It had proved reasonably tricky so far and understandably the four riders from Down High were more nervous than usual.However, after a breath-taking effort the Down High Flyers managed to finish on a zero score and the clock showed that they had also beaten the time of all the other teams.The presentation of awards quickly followed.Abby Cummiskey, Annie Gibson, Megan Nelson and Zara Sharvin entered the arena once again to receive their rosettes and coveted ticket to Balmoral Show.It was a proud day for their chef drsquoequipe Ruth Adams, their parents and indeed for Down High School.They are now looking forward to a great day out at the Bluegrass Open Championship at Balmoral Showgrounds on May ..prettyPhoto

title: Down U
story: DOWN came into this game on the back of a strong finish to their league campaign to secure second spot in Ulster and earn a Platinum final against a highly fancied Armagh team.During the league when these two teams matched up, just three weeks ago, it took until after half-time before Down registered their first score. However, at the weekend they were determined to not give Armagh a head start and to be as competitive as possible from the first whistle.During a frantic first  minutes the Down girls did not disappoint, fighting for every ball and matching Armagh in every position around the pitch.At the first water-break Down led - to Armagh - in a very even game with Clodagh Simpson scoring a great goal and the lively Orla Owens scoring two points.During the second  minute period of the first half, the Down girls raised their own standard again and pushed Armagh back into their own half.Although Down scored a further - during this period they could have had more, and it was the Armagh team and management who were the happier team to hear the half-time whistle.Scorers in this period were Annie McEvoy with - and Orla Owens again with another point. The half-time score of Down - to Armagh - did certainly not flatter Down as their performance up to then was excellent.Into the second half and Armagh tightened up a lot and restricted Down to less clearer opportunities to score.At the other end Armagh took their own chances and scored a couple of quick goals which gave them the lead for the first time in the match. A point for Owens was the only score for Down during this period.At the second water-break the score was - to - to Armagh.Into the final  minutes and Down made changes to get fresh legs on the pitch. Another Owens point, her fth of the day, levelled up the score at Down - to Armagh - with ten minutes left.Armagh scored two points take the lead for the second time and with time running out, Down went for the goal to win the game.With the ball seemingly stuck in Downrsquos attacking third they just couldnrsquot break down the Armagh defence. With time up Armagh broke up field and scored a goal with the final play to win the match.Full time: Down - Armagh -.The Down girls were disappointed with the result but the management team were delighted with their overall performance. All of the  girls used for Down played their bit.Scorers for Down were Annie McEvoy , Clodagh Simpsonand the top scorer was Orla Owens .Best performers for Down v Armagh were Lily Magee in nets, Eloise Austin, Therese Cowan, Ava McArdle, Zara Kelly, Isa McCarron, Aoe Wolfe, Anna McArdle and captain Maia Murdock but it was Orla Owens who took the player of the match award with her five points.With the Platinum All-Ireland series still to be played in the coming weeks, and the way these girls continue to improve week by week, who knows how far they can go.The management and girls would like to thank everyone for all the messages prior to the final and for all the support on the day.Down: L Magee E Austin, F M Morgan, T Cowan A McArdle, M Murdock, Z Kelly A Wolfe, I McCarron A McArdle, H Donnelly, A McEvoy O Owens, C Simpson, E McKee.Subs: D OrsquoShea, E OrsquoKane, H McGeough, R Horisk, E Farrell, C McDermott, C McGrath, G Kelly, G McMullan, E McHugh, A McKay, H Cassin, C Lundy, T Ryan, L Elmore..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  April 8%2C 1992
story: NEWCASTLE mdash The RNLI has unveiled plans for a major new pound, leboat station for Newcastle.The station, which is at the planning permission stage, will house the new Mersey class leboat which is due to arrive at the seaside town towards the end of November.If the station plans get Department of the Environment approval, the new complex will be constructed to the north of the harbour beside Newcastle Yacht Clubrsquos car park.The RNLIrsquos tractor house and the old Coastguard station will be demolished to make way for the building and a  metre-long slipway will be constructed to just beyond the high water mark.The new station will replace the existing boathouse which was built in  and, apart from some superficial work, has never been updated. The leboat crew and the shore team have to wash at a stand-pipe and the only toilets are an old Victoria public lavatory adjacent to the boathouse.In addition to a modern launching facility, which is clear of the problem-bedevilled harbour, the new station will provide the leboatmen with a crew room, equipped with toilets and showers, a kitchen, training room, lookout area and souvenir outlet.Work on the new complex is likely to take up to six months to complete and,planning permission is granted, is expected to start in June.The longest part of the work will be the construction of the slipway which will be cut down through the steep shore bank and will involve reinforced piling.Once completed the station will be ready to take delivery of the new leboat, which will be named the Bryant and Eleanor Girling after a generous RNLI benefactor.SAINTFIELD mdash Three workmen and two police officers required hospital treatment after a chemical spill in Saintfield last week.Four  gallon drums containing a mixture of acid and caustic soda, fell from a lorry on the Old Grand Jury Road at around am on Friday morning, initiating a full-scale emergency response from the Fire Brigade.Appliances from Ballynahinch and Downpatrick were sent to the scene and a specialist equipment carrying emergency tender unit was also despatched from Belfast.The incident occurred as the articulated lorry was leaving a yard on the Old Grand Jury Road carrying a large number of the chemical-containing drums.The four drums fell from the lorry, with two spilling several hundred gallons of the corrosive mixture onto the road.The lorry driver and his two assistants quickly righted the drums but suffered from fume inhalation, as did two police officers who arrived on the scene minutes after the spill.All five were treated at the Downe Hospital but were later released.STRANGFORD LOUGH mdash The Department of Environmentrsquos proposals for the management of Strangford Lough have been welcomed as a ldquotriumph of common sense.The comment comes from the Strangford Lough Nature Conservation Associationrsquos chairman, Mr Sam Davis, who is urging all lough users to unite in supporting the new administrators.Mr Davisrsquo confidence-boosting commendation of the new body comes a matter of weeks before its inaugural meeting.SLNCA was born out of the conflict felt around the Lough by controversial DoE management proposals put forward a few years ago.The recommendation to support the new administrators on the eve of their activity will be seen as a wholehearted effort by people who are anxious to make the new management structure work.Mr Davis and the Associationrsquos joint council declared after last weekrsquos meeting that the new structure represents what the loughside community have been looking for.ldquoThe new body represents a wide spectrum of community support, including the pockets of power which were driven largely by their own self-interests, he said.MOURNES mdash Health officials have been accused of ldquoplucking figures from nowhere to justy closure plans for Newcastlersquos Mourne House.The Eastern Health Council heard this week that a renovation figure of pound, for the residential home has been produced without the benefit of a quantity surveyorrsquos report.The claims were made by a deputation from the Friends of Mourne House which addressed the councilrsquos monthly meeting in Dundonald on Thursday afternoon.Friends spokesman, Mr Damian Smyth, told the meeting that the renovation figures which were produced by the Down and Lisburn Unit of Management, are completely dferent from early figures produced by the Eastern Health Boardrsquos building control officer.The officerrsquos report said Mourne House was in good repair, was free fro structural faults, and had a lespan of  years, explained Mr Smyth.He added that a more recent set of figures, produced by the unit of management on April , indicate that only minor works are needed at the home.ldquoThese latest figures say it would cost pound, to raise the standard at the home, including pound, which would have to be spent on fire safety, said Mr Smyth.ldquoThis patently does not square with the unitrsquos first report, which was used to initiate the consultation process, that it will cost a total of pound, to bring the home up to standard, said Mr Smyth. ldquoThis figure includes pound, for fire safety, pound, for a new roof, pound, for a new electrical system and pound, for a new kitchen.ldquoThese figures are bald figures produced by the unit of management with no specications and without the benefit of a quantity surveyorrsquos report, he added.PORTAFERRY mdash Portaferry has become the first town in Northern Ireland to benefit from a pioneering emergency response scheme which will save the lives of heart attack victims.The British Heart Foundation this week handed over a le-saving defibrillator which will enable doctors to provide a first response to cardiac emergencies pending the arrival of an ambulance.The presentation was made on Monday to Portaferry GPs Dr Desmond Compton and Dr David Peacock by Mr Peter Welsh, the Foundationrsquos regional organiser.The doctors believe the equipment could provide a le-saving service for , people in Portaferry and lower Ards Peninsula.It takes around  minutes from an ambulance based in Newtownards to reach the lower Ards.Even so, it would be virtually impossible to put a permanent ambulance in the area because it would be seldom used, according to the Eastern Health Boardrsquos chief ambulance officer, Mr Alan Murray.The Ambulance Service has funded the inclusion of sophisticated diagnostic facilities on the defibrillator, as well as communication systems for the doctors to ensure their immediate availability.BALLYNAHINCH mdash One of Down Districtrsquos biggest charity events of the year will take place in Ballynahinch next month.The Ballynahinch Lions k and fun runs will be staged on Saturday, May , and once again look likely to raise several thousand pounds for charity.In its third year the event has already raised pound, and the organisers are hoping that next monthrsquos event will top the pound total which was raised last year.This yearrsquos beneficiaries will be the Leukaemia Research Fund, the Marie Curie Trust, Beaconsfield, and Lions charities.The event, which is over a proven course and backed by the Northern Ireland Amateur Athletics Federation, has already become established as one of the major events on the athletics calendar and will attract runners from many parts of the province.Once again the run will begin at .pm at the Community Centre in Windmill Street, and part of the route will be through the grounds of the Montalto Estate.Lots of dferent categories have been designated by the Lions and there are prizes on offer for practically everything, from the first k runner home to the best fancy dress team.A new aspect of the event this year will be the Tracy Barr Memorial Trophy which school teams will be competing for over the K fun run course..prettyPhoto

title: Irish cycle ride in aid of local charity
story: TEN local men aim to cycle  miles from Mizen Head in Cork to Malin Head in Donegal to raise money for the Suicide Down to Zero charity.Leaving Cork on Easter Monday, the men plan to cycle  miles every day over four days, arriving into Malin Head on Thursday.The men mdash Peter Ritchie, Donnan Ritchie and Seamus Carvill from Annacloy Nicky Casement, from Drumaness Gerard Grant, from Ballynagross Eamon Dalton, from Raholp Lenny Smyth, from Ardglass Brendan Duffy, from Killough Marty McIlmail and Niall Montgomery, both from Bright mdash have already raised nearly pound,.The idea of cycling theof Ireland came from Peter, who said that his friends all quickly agreed to join in.ldquoIrsquove been thinking of doing the trip for a while now, said the  year-old joiner. ldquoWhen I mentioned it to a few of my friends, one by one they joined in until we now have a team of  going. Several of the guys have already done it before.Peter only took up cycling five years ago, but has already cycled  miles in one trip.All of the men have been putting in the extra miles to build up their stamina for the trip, hoping that their legs will push them all the way.Peter said the men decided it was important to support a local charity while they were doing the cycle.ldquoWe wanted to support a worthwhile local charity so as itrsquos about local people supporting local people helping local people, said Peter.ldquoWe chose Suicide Down to Zero as suicide is unfortunately something that touches most people in their letime and certainly has in this area.ldquoEvery penny raised will go towards reducing the number of people dying by suicide, down to zero.Peter said that he and his friends were already overwhelmed by the generosity of local people who have given money.ldquoEverything has expanded so quickly, from the guys who are willing to give it a go to the people who have donated money. We have also received a lot of support from local businessmen, he added.lsquorsquoWe hope the community will come together and support our challenge. As we push through the miles on our journey, we are reminding our family, friends, neighbours, community and entire area that there is always hope. Suicide is never the only option.rsquorsquoThe cyclists will be met by their wives, partners and children in Malin Head where a few well-earned pints will be sunk in celebration.To support the menrsquos epic cycle trip, visit https:localgiving.org fundraising sdz--of-ireland-cycle- .prettyPhoto

title: Jim recalls his fond memories of town
story: IT is often said you can take someone away from their roots, but you canrsquot take a personrsquos roots away. In the case of Jim Fitzsimons, you can take a man out of Downpatrick, but you canrsquot take Downpatrick out of a man.Jim Fitzsimons was born and reared in Downpatrick. He left the town as a young man, having graduated from Queenrsquos University, and spent the next  years or so in England where he had a successful career in further and higher education and in management training.Jim ed to Northern Ireland  years ago and for eight years lived in a cottage at Inch. Now , he and his we, Anne, live in Hillsborough where they enjoy regular visits from their three sons and seven grandchildren.But the lure of Downpatrick remains strong. When the coronavirus struck in March  and the world went into lockdown, Jim decided that the time was ripe for him to write about the town of his upbringing.The result is My Downpatrick: Reflections of  years ago, an affectionate account of happy times. For local people of a certain age, it will be a joyous trip down memory lane packed with names and places comfortingly familiar even with the passing of the years. For those who have no connection with Downpatrick, it is a story which is both educational and entertaining.Jim says he is pleased with the outcome of his efforts. ldquoI am very pleased with the book and I certainly enjoyed writing it. Growing up in Downpatrick we were modestly off, but we had all the things that we needed. It was a good place to live.Jim was born in March , six months before the start of the Second World War, the eldest of three children of William Henry Fitzsimons, a bread server, and his we, Marion. He and his younger brother and sister were reared in Saul Street in the warmth of a loving family and surrounded by many friends.He was educated at Fountain Street School and the Southwell School for Boys, where he and his schoolmates trembled in front a ldquosadistic master who ruled with the cane, before enrolling in Down High School in .Outside of school, there were plenty of opportunities to play sport, as well as trips to the cinema, church socials, the Boysrsquo Brigade and dancing. There were holidays at Tyrella, the annual BB camp, Sunday school excursions to Newcastle and trips to Coney Island, Belfast, Warrenpoint and Dundalk, among other places.It was a time when there were no supermarkets and there was an abundance of bread servers. Like his father, Jimrsquos grandfather was also a bread server, as were some of his other relatives. It was a time when bread servers they didnrsquot just serve bread. Butchers and grocers used them for deliveries. They also carried letters and parcels from the countryside to be posted in Downpatrick and also delivered a sizeable quantity of Down Recorders each week. In short, they were something of a social service.Jim writes about helping his father on his bread cart and also his paper round, which ended when he started in high school, collecting scrap metal during the Korean War and then ersying into collecting waste paper before getting a summer job in the County Surveyors Office in Downpatrick before starting university.He also writes about Downpatrick when it was a market town with a monthly fair and a weekly Saturday market. As the county town it had had many government offices and institutions, as well as hospitals and large factories offering plenty of employment, the county courthouse and two grammar schools.The factories have gone and the hospitals are much diminished since Jimrsquos childhood, but the town has grown considerably mdash its postwar population of around , is now over ,.Of Downpatrick then and now, Jim writes: ldquoDownpatrick was small enough to have a village feel about it. I donrsquot think this is still the case. People donrsquot know each other as they did in the past they live less in town centre terraced houses and more in detached houses in the outskirts.ldquoIn the past many men would go to the pub every evening, not to get drunk, but for perhaps a single drink while catching up with all the local news with friends. Going out to public houses is less common now and the public house and other entertainments is not solely for males. Women in the s and s ands were largely unseen, now they are much freer to do and go as they please. In  it was unheard of for a woman to go into a pub.He goes on: ldquoAlthough there is much to regret about the passing of the Downpatrick that I knew, it is a much better place in which to live. The slum houses that I remember are no more there are modern schools, an imposing new technical college with a nearby state-of-the-art fitness centre, a much expanded campus at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School and advanced plans for a new building for Down High School.ldquoDownpatrick has a range of educational, cultural and sporting opportunities for all ages, for those who wish to take advantage of them. All these opportunities define the quality of a town.My Downpatrick: Reflections of  years ago costs pound and is available at the Saint Patrick Centre and the Grove Post Office in Downpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Minister waste treatment refusal is blow for Arc 21
story: THE decision by Stormont Minister Nichola Mallon to refuse permission for a large scale waste treatment facility at the site of a former quarry in Newtownabbey has ramications for Newry, Mourne and Down Council.The local authority is a member of Arc which was seeking permission for the multi-million pound plant which could thermally treat , tonnes of municipal waste each year.Ms Mallon said the incinerator plant, which drew over , objections, could discourage recycling, with her decision due to be discussed at the next meeting of the local councilrsquos Neighbourhood Services Committee.Currently, black bin waste collected across the district is transported by sea for incineration in Europe, with council officials keen for the districtrsquos ratepayers to continue focusing their efforts on recycling their waste.There is currently a particular emphasis on ensuring that all food waste is not dumped in black household bins, but in brown bins whose contents is treated and turned into compost.Arc mdash which is considering the decision to refuse permission for the proposed incineration plant mdash is an umbrella waste management group representing six councils on the eastern coast.It was established in  and formally incorporated in  following a process of increasing co-operation amongst its constituent councils.The organisation works on behalf of its partner councils to guide, support and help them deliver their statutory waste management obligations, drive forward innovative waste management programmes, including developing infrastructure and address greater circularity of resources.In addition to Newry, Mourne and Down, the other councils which are members of Arc include Antrim and Newtownabbey, Belfast City, Ards and North Down, Lisburn and Castlereagh and Mid and East Antrim.Ms Mallon said: ldquoI am not persuaded that there is a need for this specic facility. In that context, I do not consider there to be any need for this proposal.A spokesperson for Arc said there was still a ldquoclear need to develop a ldquonew, modern waste infrastructure for the region.It said the proposed facility would boost recycling, reduce emissions and provide green electricity.ldquoIt is essential that Arc has an opportunity to review the planning reasons behind the ministerrsquos statement and we will carefully consider todayrsquos announcement in that light over the next few days, added the spokesperson..prettyPhoto

title: Museum to shut doors over Easter
story: THE Down County Museum in Downpatrick will be closed over Easter.The announcement came just hours after Newry, Mourne and Down Council refused to confirmthe museum would be open to the public over the busy Easter holiday period.Initially, the local authority would only confirm that a decision on the Easter opening would be made in ldquodue course, but within hours of informing the Recorder of this and the paper being printed, it was finally revealed that the museum would remain closed.The council has subsequently confirmed that a reduced staff team is delivering services at the museum mdash which only opens between am and pm from Wednesday and Friday mdash and it is ldquowith regret that it will not be open at Easter.The Recorder understands that are six vacant staff positions at the museum and that up to five staff members are currently off sick.Adverts to recruit new museum staff have been published this week with the local authority looking to appoint and assistant curator, education and outreach officer, museum assistant and a cultural assistant.While council officials are hoping to have new employees in place next month, the local authority has not made clear how many new staff are being recruited and what the Downpatrick museumrsquos future opening hours will be.The museum has been at the centre of a controversial staff restructuring process.Downpatrick SDLP councillor Dermot Curran said thee council should have made it clear last week that the museum would be closed at Easter.Welcoming plans to recruit new employees, he suggested that councillors should be briefed at a one-off council meeting by senior local authority officials on exactly what is happening at the museum.ldquoI remain disappointed that the museum will not be open at Easter. While I understand that work is underway to recruit new staff, many will be disappointed the museum is closed as it is one of the many jewels in the districtrsquos tourism crown, he said.ldquoTourism is something we do very well in our district, but not opening what is a county museum at this time of year is frustrating and very disappointing.He added: ldquoWe need a fully ing museum in the heart of the county town. The Down County Museum is one of the districtrsquos main attractions and the visitors it draws spend time in Downpatrick and support other businesses, especially those in the hospitality sector which boosts our economy.ldquoGiven tourism is a prime driver for our economy, I am very disappointed that our museum will be shut to visitors over the Easter period and know this view will be shared by many.Alliance councillor Patrick Brown has also criticised the councilrsquos decision to keep the museum closed over Easter.He also called for staff to be moved from Newry to alleviate what he described as ldquostaffing pressures.He said: ldquoI am frustrated to see yet another blow to the Down Museum. Our county museum is so important to the area, and leading into the summer months it should be able to play its essential part in our local tourism industry.ldquoThis is particularly important this year, as we try to bounce back from the pandemic. We have already seen huge controversy over councilrsquos downgrading of the museum, and the news that the museum will remain closed over Easter is very unwelcome.ldquoI, along with other councillors, have secured a full review of museum services across the district as a whole, which is due to start this month. I look forward to seeing the results of this so that we can begin to make changes. Council urgently needs to resolve these staffing pressures, reflect on how the downgrading of the museum has contributed to them and seek the urgent reopening of the Down Museum.He added: ldquoI am disappointed that the Down Museum has become another example of how services are being moved from Downpatrick to Newry. I see all the potential Downpatrick has to be a thriving city, but time and again our services are being redirected to Newry.ldquoI want to see Downpatrick on the map as a destination town for the whole of Northern Ireland, andelected to the Assembly in May, I will fight to bring an end to the lack of delivery for Downpatrick that we have seen from the political establishment in the area for so long.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokesman confirmed that the organisation is currently operating with a reduced team of staff to deliver the services at the Downpatrick museum.He said: ldquoIt is therefore with regret that the museum opening times over the Easter holiday period will be Wednesday to Friday between am and pm..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry man Peter hoping to lose 50lbs in 50 weeks during fundraiser for Air Ambulance NI
story: PORTAFERRY man Peter McGrattan set himself a target of raising vital funds to Air Ambulance NI by losing lbs in  weeks before his th birthday.He started last October and has already lost  pounds, with just  pounds to go before his birthday on September .Peter is a driver for Coach Connections and coaches the Down U- hurling team in his spare time.He explained why he wanted to get involved in such a public way of losing weight.lsquoMy father Kevin was involved in a road traffic collision in Portaferry in , sustaining a traumatic head injury, said Peter.ldquoThankfully Air Ambulance NI were there on the day to treat him and swtly transferred him to Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. We are so thankful to have an air ambulance here in Northern Ireland, so when I decided to take on this challenge, I knew I wanted to raise funds for them.The father of two added: ldquoI have raised over pound, already and am overwhelmed by people generosity. I would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone who has contributed to my challenge.Grace Williams, area fundraising manager for Air Ambulance NI, said: ldquoI want to thank Peter for supporting our lesaving service.ldquoSince Air Ambulance NI first launched in July , our service has been tasked on , occasions. With a fundraising need of pound, per day, we greatly appreciate this support and would encourage people to get behind Peterrsquos unique fundraising challenge.ldquoBy sponsoring Peter, you really are keeping our team flying and saving lives, brains and limbs. A huge thank you goes out to everyone who has already taken the time to support Peter mdash we canrsquot fly without you.Find out more about the Air Ambulance by visiting www.airambulanceni.org alternatively you can contact the charity directly by emailing info@airambulanceni.org or calling   .To support Peterrsquos fundraiser, visit https:www.justgiving fundraising peter-mcgrattan..prettyPhoto

title: Schools and WI group unite to plant 500 trees
story: PUPILS from three Dowpatrick schools joined members of the Womenrsquos Institute to plant  trees in Dunleath Park last week.Students from Down High School, Blackwater Integrated College and St Patrickrsquos Grammar School all helped in the local environmental event.The tree-planting event originated from ecologically-minded students at Down High School, who were the winners of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos local democracy Dragonsrsquo Den style debate which took place last October.The notice of potion debated by six schools was on the theme of lsquoProtecting the Environment, Local Communities Take Actionrsquo.The students put forward their ideas on organising an Eco-Fun Day and a tree planting event for the local community to promote and demonstrate the councilrsquos commitment to tackling climate change.Members of the Quoile Womenrsquos Institute were also invited to assist local pupils to plant the trees in recognition of the WIrsquos Plant a Tree for our Future climate change initiative.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason said: ldquoI am delighted that we have been able to fulfil the notice of motion debated by Down High School during councilrsquos celebrations of Local Democracy Week.ldquoThe pupils from Down High School Eco Group understand that it is their generationrsquos duty to continue to tackle climate change.ldquoThe council understands the importance of trees and their role in keeping us and our environment healthy and we are delighted to support the pupils by planting  trees here at Dunleath Park today..prettyPhoto

title: Slieve Croob to Paris Marathon
story: IT was an action packed weekend with members both junior and senior involved in races of multiple types and distance in several dferent venues.Saturday was all about the hills with Ollie Robinson trying out for selection in the NIMRA U- trials and Aaron McGrady taking on a fell race in England.The NIMRA U-trials took place on Slieve Croob on a day where blue skies and pale sunshine enhanced the occasion for all concerned.The format of the day mirrored that taken by the events last year because of Covid- a time trial over the .k route from the bottom along the path to the top of Slieve Croob and back down over the mountain side, followed by the actual race over the same route a short time later.The thinking behind not changing this was so that local runners did not have an unfair advantage from doing a route recce beforehand.EDAC was well represented by Ollie Robinson and Jacob Crawford, both only , and out to have a good hard mountain run.They were also keen to seethey might get a call up to the International U- Mountain Running Championships which will be taking place in Saluzzo, Italy this June.They tackled the tricky course with gusto and gave it a good blast.Most runners improved their time trial time to race time considerably showing a certain element of race tactics of holding something in reserve for the actual race since selection was based on race time only.Ollie came in first overall in a time of . and Jacob was fthacross the finish line. The team will be announced in due course.Aaron McGrady was in the Peak District along with  other runners for the annual Chicken Run which is a fell race approximately . miles distance and includes , feet of climbing.He had a strong run and placed second overall in a time of .. Aaron was more than happy to be runner-up to the winner Steve Vernon, who is a triple British cross country and mountain running champion ndash He also set the Chicken Run course record in .Steve and Aaron were the only two to break  minutes for the testing course and only nine runners made it home in under the hour so it was a creditable performance from Aaron from all angles.Sunday saw the rescheduled Titanic K. This race was due to take place in  but was called off due to Covid-.At the time a large number of runners deferred their entry to a new date in  but this also fell foul of restrictions at that time so for some runners this was a two year-old ticket.With the ers bolstered by new entrants there were  excited participants in the Harbour Estate ready for action.Paul Lloyd was delighted to finally take to the roads in a race as he has been hampered by a long term injury and has only managed a modicum of training.He last raced in June  so it was a long time coming.He finished in . which placed him th overall. This is a good marker for further improvement as he s to previous form and he commented on how good it felt to be back at a mass participation event. Hopefully he will now feel ready to enter more races in the near future.Manchester MarathonAs anyone who has done a marathon will know, the preparation required is gruelling. Most runners start months in advance and gradually increase their mileage so that they have the stamina to cope comfortably with . miles.They also need to include speed workthey want to set a good time so it is a juggling process.Gordy Graham, coached by Ryan Maxwell, had followed his schedule to the letter and had many promising race results in his build up so it was a hammer blow when he developed a knee injury with only three weeks to go.He eased off the miles in the hope that it would settle and right up to the morning of the marathon, he was debating whether racing was in his best interests.This head versus heart is not a new thing to runners. With the hours spent training for that day, sitting it out would have been too much to bear.In the end he set off with equal amounts of hope and caution and for the first hour or so maintained the pace that he needed to match his . personal best set in Belfast last year.He was in a group banging out miles at an incredible . minutes per mile pace and he felt pretty good until mile .At this point the niggle became enough to disrupt his natural rhythm and as a result his pace wavered. However, true to form he persisted to the line recording .. as he passed the tape.This result is one that would cause celebration for most and it is, in fact, his second fastest marathon but for Gordy there is still a time out there that he wants to achieve and we know that when he has assessed and treated his injury, he will be back pushing for his goal.We wish him luck in his recovery and future endeavours.Hannah Somani was also out chasing specic targets firstly to better her time of . which she set in London Marathon last October and secondly to come home in under three hours. This sub-three barrier is regarded as a holy grail for many and for Hannah being so close on in London was enough to convince her to give it another shot.She continued consistent training throughout the autumn and into the winter with multiple sessions per week as well as long runs at weekends.On her recent trip to Downpatrick she was so committed to the plan that she ran -odd miles on the morning of Jimmyrsquos Ten before heading to the start line.She then went on to run quick enough in the K to lead with two other high performing EDAC ladiestoclinch victory in the team competition.All this must have stood her in good stead as she absolutely nailed it on Sunday. She arrived at the start with quiet resolve and executed her race with precision pacing.Her time of .. was well deserved after her hard work and she was naturally over the moon. Super work, Hannah.Steph Graham was equally determined in her approach. A small matter of a wedding and a baby in the last  months might seem reason to hold back from committing to race targets but when your husband is also your coach then the lines become blurred.Gordy has had prior mention above for his own race but Steph would be quick to acknowledge his part in her achievements. She entered Manchester due largely to his encouragement as she had doubts as to whether she would be ready in time.She had been hacking chunks off her marathon times in the last few years and in Berlin  she ran . so sub . was her aim. This was a big ask as training with a young baby is never easy but she pulled it off with style.Gordy was brimming over with pride when she finished in ... Steph deserves kudos for this performance but even more so for the fact that she had to resort to the treadmill for daily miles.Despite the tedium of running miles looking at a wall, she never missed a session and her hard graft has paid off. What a team.Same distance but dferent city ndash Dee Murray had decided that Paris in the spring would provide the incentive to train over the winter months and he had racked up his miles motivated by excitement of a European marathon.The day dawned bright but chilly and it took a bit of effort to get warm enough to shed the layers before the start.Fortunately once they were lined up on the famous Champs Elyseacutees, the sun came out in fulland the , runners had perfect racing conditions for the rest of the day.Dee ran with his usual metronomic rhythm ticking off the miles and the iconic landmarks as he ran the winding route.Apart from a bit of cramp in the last couple of miles, he felt comfortable and was delighted to get a sub three hour finish in .. shaving a few seconds off his previous best which had held since .Dee is known as lsquoMr Consistentrsquo and running as quickly as he did five years ago endorses that nickname no end. It is also worth a mention that he placed a commendable , out of ,. A good job well done.With the racing season in full flow, EDAC club members were quick to get signed up on the recent membership night so that they can keep training and also avail of the club discount when entering races.They might also have been encouraged by the raffle which was held at the sign-up. Congratulations to the lucky winners who snagged bottles of wine and Easter eggs.Patrick Smith even won a free entry to Comber K. He will undoubtedly be looking to raise a crowd to keep him company.Whether you are a cub member or not, why not have a look at the list of upcoming races  Visit https:athleticsni.org Fixtures. There is also the weekly parkrun at Dunleath playing fields.More info at https:www.parkrun.org.uk dunleathplayingfields  .On the other handyou are looking for like minded people to help you get race ready then do get in touch with membership@eastdownac and you will be made most welcome at East Down Athletics Club.Senior training is Monday and Thursday pm with circuits also available to members on Tuesday and Friday nights..prettyPhoto

title: royal black leader hails opening of magnificent new headquarters in loughgall
story: Rumours of Article  move to suspend Northern Ireland Protocol are credible says Lord Empey   I would not have backed the Good Friday AgreementI had known of side deals such as the de facto amnesty for Provos onlyNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleRoyal Black leader hails opening of ‘magnicent’ new headquarters in LoughgallThe leader of the Royal Black Institution has hailed the opening of its new headquarters as an event that delivers an enduring legacy for future generations.By The NewsroomSunday, rd April , : pm  "       "  Sovereign Grand Master Rev William Anderson, speaking at the official opening of the state-of-the-art centre in Loughgall, said: “There can be no doubt that this day marks an important point in our journey as an institution.“It is a time in our journey to give thanks for the past, to be assured of the present and to look forward in anticipation to the future.”Saturday’s grand opening ceremony took place after a colourful and dignied parade of more than , members of the institution, accompanied by  bands, through the picturesque Co Armagh village.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The Royal Black Institution held a parade on Saturday to mark the opening of a new state-of-the-art headquarters in LoughgallGuests included the Grand Master of the Orange Order, Edward Stevenson.Spectators lined the route in the sunshine as the midday procession – headed by the institution’s officers and led by Moneyslane Flute Band – made its way from Red Lion Road, past the new headquarters on Main Street and into the country park. A ‘Leaders’ Legacy’ exhibition – focusing on past sovereign grand masters of the Royal Black – formed part of the event, including the unveiling and dedication of a bust of Sir Norman Stronge.The bust was unveiled by James Kinghan, a grandson of Sir Norman, and Andy Gray, a Royal Black member, who was a driver for the late senior unionist politician, and dedicated by the Grand Chaplain, Rev Nigel Reid. withImperial Grand Chaplains Raymond Adams and Rev Dr Phil Rimmer, Imperial Grand Treasurer David Livingstone and Imperial Grand Chaplain Rev Nigel Reid" "" width"" srcset"https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMNzYMjk.jpg width w, https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMNzYMjk.jpg width w" layout"intrinsic" class"i-amphtml-layout-intrinsic i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"intrinsic" withImperial Grand Chaplains Raymond Adams and Rev Dr Phil Rimmer, Imperial Grand Treasurer David Livingstone and Imperial Grand Chaplain Rev Nigel Reid" fallback layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"Sovereign Grand Master Rev William AndersonwithImperial Grand Chaplains Raymond Adams and Rev Dr Phil Rimmer, Imperial Grand Treasurer David Livingstone and Imperial Grand Chaplain Rev Nigel ReidRev Anderson laid a wreath at the newly unveiled bust and a lament was played on the bagpipes by Joshua Truesdale.Sir Norman, who led the institution from  to , was a former speaker in the Northern Ireland Parliament and was the holder of the Military Cross for gallantry at the Battle of the Somme in . He and his son James, also a member of the institution, were brutally murdered by the IRA at their Tynan Abbey home in January .Speaking on Saturday, the Rev Anderson said the organisation was celebrating “building for the future”.Imperial Grand Chaplain Raymond Adams inside the new headquartersHe said: “Our new headquarters building is a sign of our courage and determination. “Just like title: mobile network upgrade might cause tv signal issues
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe upgrades to the mobile networks may interfere with televisions that receive signals through an aerial, such as Freeview, BT, TalkTalk and YouView.Potential issues may range from intermittent sound, to pixellation problems, to a complete loss of signal.Restore TV are offering free support to anyone who may be affected by the issues.Restore TV is run by an organisation called Digital Mobile Spectrum Limitedwhich is owned by EE, Virgin Media O, Three and Vodafone.Their role is to ensure that people can still watch free to view TVmobile service upgrades cause TV interference.:Ben Roome, CEO of Restore TV, said: "We know just how important TV is to inform, entertain and provide welcome company."Restore TV exists to ensure we all can continue to access free to view TV as mobile services are improved across the country.”"If you see new TV interference, we’re on hand to help you resolve the issue. We can send a Restore TV filter, free of charge, for you to fit between your aerial lead and TV or set-top box to remove mobile signals and allow you to watch free to view TV as normal."Full instructions are included, and we can provide further advice online and by phoneneeded."In most instances, fitting the filter will resolve any issues, butthis isn’t the case, we may also be able to arrange a follow-up visit from a Restore TV engineer at no cost, depending on eligibility."Cable and satellite TV, such as Sky or Virgin, are not affected, but viewers with these services who also watch free to view TV through an aerial can receive a free Restore TV filter..removeViewers who receive interference on their TV should call the free number     or visit the Restore TV website

title: revealed number people covid wales now
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Office for National Statisticspublished its regular weekly release analysing results from the COVID- Infection Survey.And, while the overall findings showed a positive trend UK wide, there is some cause for concern in Wales.While new case numbers have been falling – according to Public Health Wales , the overall number of covid positive people in Wales might be a lot higher than first thought.At this time, the ONS data estimates that as many as one-in- people in Wales currently have covid.This excludes those in hospitals and care homes, and only considers private households.The ONS estimates that , people in Wales, or . per cent of the population, has covid at this time.It includes all known iants of the potentially deadly virus, with the Omicron BA. iant still the most dominant.In recent days, the PHW figures show that new cases of the virus are more prevalent in Blaenau Gwent and Torfaen than anywhere  in Wales.The ONS study uses the percentage of positive results from tests carried out, to paint a complete picture across Wales, and the rest of the UK.However, it is worth noting that there are fewer tests than ever before being carried out.It comes as a result of free testing coming to an end – with only those in healthcare and care settings required to regularly test.What’s more, symptomatic people or close contacts are no longer required to take a test, which are no longer free.Read more: Latest covid stats for Newport and Wales: Another five deathsRead more: Covid lab blunder could have caused , deathsSarah Crofts, head of analytical outputs for the COVID- infection survey, said: “While infections remain high, there are early signs in our latest data that they may no longer be increasing in some parts of the UK..remove"Across English regions, there is a mixed picture in trends and we have seen a welcome decrease in Scotland.   “However, rates in Wales continue to rise and the trend in Northern Ireland is uncertain."It is too early to sayinfections have peaked in England and Scotland. title: steve pagliuca aims keep chelsea habitual winners bid successful
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Boston Celtics co-owner watched Thomas Tuchel’s side thump Southampton - on Saturday, and has now laid out his plans should he win the race to buy the Blues.The four consortiums battling for the Premier League club will submit final offers to New York merchant bank Raine Group on Thursday, with Pagliuca the latest to confirm a list of pledges including plans to rebuild the Stamford Bridge stadium. vw,vw,px, px"Roman Abramovich, pictured, will sell Cha after  years owning the west London club “During this hugely signicant week for Cha, we would first like to wish Thomas and the Cha squad the very best of luck ahead of tonight’s Champions League match against Real Madrid,” said Pagliuca.“Having witnessed a great - win against Southampton last week, I hope to see a comeback for the ages against Real Madrid in the quarter-final second leg.“This process has been a disconcerting time for the football club and fans.“Throughout my le and career, my ethos has always been to operate quietly, with integrity, and let my actions and results speak loudly.“However, it is imperative to clary and assure supporters about our bid group and its commitments, to emphasize how seriously we take our potential responsibility to Cha.“Our first focus and goal is to make strategic investments to continue competing for championships and trophies.“We will support our players and managers to make sure that Cha are habitual winners and title contenders, whether in the Premier League, Champions League or the Women’s Super League .“In addition, we will continue to invest in the youth academy to develop the stars of the future and we would not be in this processwe did not have an exciting and inclusive vision for Cha.”.removeCo-Owner Steve Pagliuca and Team President Rich Gotham are red carpet ready #NBAAwards pic qmvYVdZ— Boston CelticsJune , Russian-Israeli billionaire Roman Abramovich put Cha up for sale on March , amid Russia’s continued invasion of Ukraine.The -year-old was then sanctioned by the UK Government on March , with Downing Street claiming to have proven his links to Russia President Vladimir Putin.Cha have been granted a special Government licence to continue operating, though under strict terms.Abramovich cannot profit from Cha’s sale, but had already vowed to write off the club’s £.billion debt.As well as Pagliuca, the other three contenders to buy the Blues are the Chicago Cubs-owning Ricketts family, LA Dodgers part-owner Todd Boehly and British business titan Jonathan Goldstein, and Sir Martin Broughton and Lord Sebastian Coe. vw,vw,px, px"Stamford Bridge could be set for a revamp Pagliuca has now revealed his plans for Cha should he make a success of his takeover bid.“Our second focus will be to continue to cherish and preserve the legacy and traditions of the club,” said Pagliuca.“In over  years of ownership of the Boston Celtics, we have not once considered changing the name, colours, or logo of the club. This is our guarantee to Cha fans.“Not only are we committed to remaining at the home of Cha, Stamford Bridge, but we are inspired to renovate or redevelop the stadium.“Cha is a world-class team, in a world-class city, with world-class fans: it deserves a world-class stadium.Its a big week of football! 👀 pic dHPapfrih— Cha FCApril , “Our third focus will be having a signicant positive impact in the community.“We believe passionately that clubs have a social responsibility, and we will continue to support the Cha Foundation and its impressive work in education, health and well-being, and ersity and inclusion both locally and globally.“Cha should be the pride of London for its on and off-field accomplishments. It has fans all over the world and we will not tolerate bullying, anti-Semitism, racism, or any other form of hateful speech – and neither should our fans.“Ultimately, fans will see our commitment and, we hope, trust us to stay true to our values on and off the pitch. title: lord karan bilimoria joins ricketts familys bid buy chelsea

These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Cha fan and founding chairman of the UK India Business Council adds political clout to the Chicago Cubs-owning Ricketts’ attempt to buy the Blues.US multi-billionaires Ken Grfin and Dan Gilbert have teamed up with Tom and Laura Ricketts to put together a hefty offer for Cha, with the sale expected to reach a sports-franchise record £billion.And now Bilimoria has joined the consortium with plans to act as a club ambassador should the Ricketts bid prove successful. vw,vw,px, px"Lord Karan Bilimoria, left, with Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer, centre, “I founded Cobra Beer just down the road from Stamford Bridge and have been a season ticket holder for many years,” said Bilimoria.“So when Tom Ricketts approached me to discuss a leading role in his bid group, there was no way I could refuse.“Tom and the wider group have a proven track record of running successful sports teams and a strong vision for both the club and the local community.”Russian-Israeli billionaire Roman Abramovich put Cha up for sale on March , amid Russia’s continued invasion of Ukraine.A huge #UCL clash!Come on Cha! 👊 pic NVCRKecZX— Cha FCApril , The -year-old was then sanctioned by the UK Government on March , with Downing Street claiming to have proven his links to Vladimir Putin.Cha have been granted a special Government licence to continue operating, though under strict terms.Abramovich cannot profit from Cha’s sale, but had already vowed to write off the club’s £.bn debt.The Ricketts family, LA Dodgers part-owner Todd Boehly and British business titan Jonathan Goldstein, Sir Martin Broughton and Lord Sebastian Coe, and Boston Celtics co-owner Steve Pagliuca are the final four contenders to buy the Blues..removeBilimoria founded Cobra Beer in a flat in Fulham in , and now chairs the Change the Race Ratio, a body set up to champion ethnic minority ersity in UK business.He was appointed Lord Bilimoria of Cha in , becoming the first Zoroastrian Parsi to sit in the House of Lords, as an independent crossbench peer.Bilimoria also become the first Indian-born chancellor of a Russell Group university in Great Britain when taking up that post at Birmingham University in .“We have always been clear that having local expertise and perspectives on our bid is vital,” said Tom Ricketts.“Given Lord Bilimoria’s unparalleled credentials and his love for Cha, he is the perfect addition to our team.”.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Lord Karan Bilimoria joins Ricketts family us bid to buy Cha article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: uefa accused touch fans champions league proposals
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityEuropean football’s governing body and its president Aleksander Ceferin praised supporters for their role in thwarting attempts to form a European Super League almost a year ago.However, those same fans feel new proposals from UEFA to increase the number of Champions League group stage matches from six to  from  and to reserve two qualication berths based on historic European performance rather than domestic achievement will create a “cartel” of rich clubs and damage domestic competitions.The Football Supporters’ Association’s Premier League Network says these proposals should be rejected by UEFA, whose ruling executive committee is expected to make a final decision on the Champions League revamp in Vienna on May .Fan groups from the FSA’s Premier League Network met last night  were unanimous in opposition to UEFA’s proposed Champions League changes that will entrench the richest clubs, damage the football pyramid  rip off fans.The FSA supports their stance.https:t.co pZvHOmGBlH pic ZDeSVNwy— The FSAApril , “We are united in opposition to proposals to reform the Champions League that are a back door attempt at ato the discredited idea of a European Super League,” the Network’s statement said.“Last year, it was our supporter groups that united to force the collapse of the European Super League. At the time, UEFA told us that fans were the heart of the game and promised fans’ views would be centre stage in deciding what came next.“So it is with great dismay that we now face the prospect of changes to the Champions League that will mean many more group games being played and entry for some clubs being based on a historical five-year ‘UEFA Club Co-efficient’..remove“These proposals will only widen the gap between rich clubs and the rest, at the same time wrecking domestic league calendars, with the expectation that fans sacrice yet more time and money attending meaningless group games.”UEFA’s executive committee initially approved reforms to its men’s club competitions, including the Champions League, on April  last year, but to very little fanfare or publicity as it happened in the hours after the Super League had been launched.The increase from six matches to , plus a further play-off round to determine eight of the last , along with the inclusion of two-co-efficient places were approved at that time. The group stage would increase from  to  teams, with all teams playing in one big league and facing other teams under a seeded ‘Swiss system’.UEFA has looked at the plans again in the wake of the Super League collapse, however the proposals clearly still provide far too many concessions to the big clubs in the view of Premier League fans.Under its latest proposal, teams could only qualy via the co-efficientthey finished immediately outside the regular Champions League spots, to avoid them leapfrogging rivals who finish in a higher position. However, it is understood teams could also win the FA Cup and qualy via co-efficient, whereas FA Cup winners with a lesser European pedigree would not. vw,vw,px, px"UEFA president Aleksander Ceferin “It is irresponsible and out of touch to even consider doubling the number of home games that fans will have to attend before the last - knock-out round begins,” the Network added.“This will be compounded by the cost of living crisis that is hitting Europe. Furthermore, we do not see how increasing the requirement for teams and fans to fly around Europe is compatible with UEFA’s environmental commitments.“Premier League fans do not want  group games involving a small cartel of rich clubs further distorting competitive balance. We want strong, competitive domestic leagues, an equal opportunity for all to qualy for UEFA competitions based on sporting merit, along with a fairer distribution of the game’s wealth from the revenues those competitions earn.“Last year we engaged in constructive discussions with UEFA President Ceferin who made a commitment that fans would be listened to in this process. Our collective voice is unied and our position clear.“We call on UEFA to demonstrate that it acts in the interests of the wider football community and its supporters, not just the interests of the few rich investors and state-owned clubs that, less than a year ago, tried to destroy the European football family.”European Leagues, the umbrella group which includes the Premier League among its membership, has sought since the beginning of the consultation to limit the increase in matches to eight rather than , and to grant the two extra Champions League qualication places to the domestic champions of countries not currently represented in the group stage, rather than on club co-efficient..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: UEFA accused of being out of touch with fans over Champions League proposals article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe youngster was born to Flo, a three-year-old Linne’s two-toed sloth, and Reggie at Dudley Zoo and Castleon April .DZC curator Richard Brown said staff were “thrilled” at the arrival of the first baby sloth to be born at the West Midlands zoo in its -year history, which keepers spotted as they took Flo and Reggie their supper.“It was a lovely surprise for staff to discover the baby, especially as Flo wasn’t showing signs of being in labour during the day,” he said.Flo arrived at the zoo in August  as part of a European breeding programme.Gestation typically lasts about six months, but keepers only realised Flo was pregnant in recent weeks when they noticed movement around her stomach. vw,vw,px, px"The baby sloth will be named in the coming weeks Mr Brown added: “We know the news will be as exciting for our visitors as it is for our staff as we’re very aware our pair of sloths are our most popular animals on site.“The baby seems healthy and alert as it snuggles up to mum, who is doing wonderfully and taking first-time motherhood in her stride, while dad, Reggie looks on proudly.”The sex of the baby will be confirmed in the coming weeks, after which keepers will decide on a name..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Baby sloth takes keepers by surprise at zoo article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: no six nations today   find wales play next watch
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySimply put the players need a rest. Weeks three and five are typically break weeks during the championship to give the teams times to recuperate.If you are desperate to see how Round  will play out though, you don’t have long to wait. Games will resume next weekend during the Guinness Six Nations match at the Principality Stadium, Cardf. Picture: PA" alt"Penarth Times: Wales Jac Morgan is tackled by Scotlands Hamish Watson and Duhan van der Merweduring the Guinness Six Nations match at the Principality Stadium, Cardf. Picture: PA" class"editor-image"Wales Jac Morgan is tackled by Scotlands Hamish Watson and Duhan van der Merweduring the Guinness Six Nations match at the Principality Stadium, Cardf. Picture: PA Twickenham Stadium, London​Saturday, February .pmNew Wales flanker Jac Morgan admits playing at Twickenham next week would be special given the historic rugby rivalry between England and Wales.Morgan won his first cap on Saturday as reigning Six Nations champions Wales bounced back from a Dublin drubbing against Ireland to beat Scotland - in Cardf.The Welsh-speaking Ospreys openside says he was so nervous before kick-off that he almost forgot the words of the national anthem ‘Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau’.“It’s always a dream to play for your country from a young age,” said the -year-old.“Growing up England is one of the biggest games with the rivalry between the two countries over the years.“Everybody knows how big the game is with the history between the two sides."Morgan produced an impressive debut display last weekend, as Wales revived their Six Nations title hopes before heading to Twickenham next Saturday.Courtney Lawes has resumed full training in time to reinforce the middle phase of England’s Guinness Six Nations title push.Lawes was unable to play in the opening two rounds of the tournament because of concussion but has now completed histo play protocols and comes into contention to face Wales next Saturday..removeDefence coach, Anthony Seibold, said: "Courtney trained fully today , which is obviously really good news for himself and England. He looked sharp."Meanwhile, Wasps flanker Jack Willis is set to make his first appearance in a year after finally recovering from the serious knee injury sustained against Italy at Twickenham in the  championship.England v Wales Six Nations: How to watch on TV, live streamThe England v Wales Six Nations match kicks off at .pm on Saturday, February .You can watch coverage on ITV or live stream the game via ITV Hub.Alternatively,you cant make it to a screen, you can also listen live on BBC Radio  Live Sports Extra. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. Do something instead‘Don’t worry!’ How often have we heard that and how often do we say it to others  I suspect it’s being said quite often at the present time, when there seems to be so much to be worried about, writes Rev. Ron Elsdon.By The NewsroomSunday, rd April , : am  "       "  There’s the state of the Health Service, the never-ending fallout from Brexit, the war in Ukraine, and the spiralling cost of living which is already inflicting so much hardship on so many. ‘Don’t worry!’ But the problem is that it’s far easier said than done. So when you come across it in the bible as well, you could be excused for writing it off as unrealistic. Please stay with me for a few moments, however, while I try to explain. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Much of the bible comes from times and situations of great stress and worry, so it’s not simply saying ‘Don’t worry!’ or offering you a technique like meditation to help you cope. It points you to something rather more than that. I offer you two examples where it offers you responses that are practical – strategies,you like.Ron ElsdonFirstly, Paul directs people to pray instead, and to pepper their prayers with thanksgiving . The trouble is that we’re so good at finding things to complain about, often trivialities, that finding things to give thanks for doesn’t come easily, even to people who pray regularly, but why not switch course and actually do it, then keep on doing it  Then, says Paul, the protecting peace of God is there to be discovered, even in the midst of stressful situations. Secondly, Jesus talks about worry in the Sermon on the Mount . When it consumes us, he says, what we need is a new set of ambitions which point us beyond ourselves “Seek first God’s kingdom and God’s righteousness” is His command to His followers. As I write, I’m thinking about a local politician, one I shan’t be voting for. I know he spends Christmas Day at a place for the homeless, helping to serve up hot meals for that I admire him greatly. As I write, hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians are fleeing the army of a tyrant from the east, many with nowhere to go in freezing weather. In neighbouring countries, churches and other organisations are swinging into action to help support these folk in their hour of desperate need. So, in their dferent ways, Jesus’ and Paul’s words in the bible are saying to us all, ‘Don’t worry! Do something instead.’Read: Covid travel requirement set to change

WIT  WISDOM: This too shall passWith our recent fine weather I’ve been doing more than my usual five-to- miles a day walking, an activity that, with many of my countrymen, I developed during the lockdown, when there was little  to do, writes Adam Harbinson.By The NewsroomSunday, th April , : am  "       "  Last week was idyllic as I walked along the Donegal coast from Moville to Greencastle it was magical, and it struck me again, that while we all know the value of regular exercise, fresh air and social engagement, we might never really know just how beneficial such days are for our physical and mental health.But what perhaps, on the flipside, will our memories of - be in  years time  We’ll be asking ourselves, how on Earth did we remain sane  Brexit has wreaked havoc on our economy, piled on top of which was Covid-. I can still feel the cloud of gloom that settled on me when a radio announcer was suggesting that all over s would not be allowed outside the door of their homes for  weeks.Thankfully it didn’t quite come to that.Then came the murderous war in Ukraine, with pictures being flashed onto our screens of European families hiding in cellars in fear or their lives, not to mention the bloody carnage. But how does this bad news affect our mental health To further exacerbate my potential for anxiety I can tell you that five of my close friends and family members are suffering from le-threatening health problems one has even invited me to his rd birthday party, when he and I know full well that in reality it’s a ‘going away’ party. I’m in my mid-s and while I feel as mentally and physically fit as I was in my s, the thing I hate about my age is that so many of my contemporaries are dropping like flies.So, what can we do to protect ourselves  Firstly we must regulate our intake of deadly news regular exercise and getting out into the countryside is helpful too. Gratitude is of vital importance, so let’s get a pen and paper and make a list of the many aspects of our lives for which we can be truly grateful.But is that enough  You might say no, but since there might be little we can do to help our suffering brothers and sisters, we must recognise the need for serenity to accept the things we cannot change and thecourage to change the things we can.One thing’s for sure this too will pass. title: curry s fun park opens in portrush
story: AFTER months of waiting, Currys Fun Park in Portrush is finally open! The eagerly anticipated successor to the popular Barrys Amusements opened its doors for the first time on Saturday amid great excitement. Hundreds of people young and old filed through the doors all afternoon as the magic ed to Portmagic - and just in time for Easter. The good news is that Currys is now up and running, boasting all the old Barrys favourites and adding some new ones too. And for those with old Barrys tokens - no, you cant use them, but you can help the RNLI by dropping them into collection boxes dotted around the complex. The fun park has chosen the charity as its partner - a thoughtful gesture given the important work volunteers do in the waters off the north coast. But for now, after two years of zero craic because of the pandemic, all roads lead to the Port and what promises to be a fun-filled holiday period. title: april showers keep them shorter
story: Spring has finally sprung and with rising energy costs there is no better time to dust off old habits and create some new ones that are good for your pocket and the environment. Start by thinking how much water you are using each day. Whether you are washing your hands, cleaning endless amounts of dishes or getting through that mountain of washing, you start to realise just how important water is and the sheer amount we use. NI Water’s Environmental Outreach  Learning Officer, Anna Killen, explains how we can save water by looking at everyday habits, “It’s amazing to think that each day each person uses around  litres of water! However, saving water can be really easy, there are simple things we can all do that can make a huge dference. “Did you know that the average time people in Northern Ireland spend in the shower is  minutes, over % of people still overfill the kettle and less than frac of people have a waterbutt ”  “We want that to change and it’s easy, start by looking at small changes for example, your kettle, since working from home it has have been working overtime, but just fill with as much water as you need. Overfilling can use twice as much energy and water, each time you boil. “With rising energy costs, it might be time to think about reducing the time spent in the shower, hot water costs money! Why not try the  minute shower challenge, put on your favourite  minute song and seeyou can finish before the end.” To help you embed with these new habits and ‘Get Water Fit’, complete our online water audit at https:www.getwaterfit or take part in water saving challenges and receive your free water saving items including  minute shower timer, toothy timers and swell gel bags for the garden. Some water saving tips:  Turn off the tap when brushing your teeth - A running tap can use  litres ofwater per minute.  Use a bowl for washing vegetables - Then you can reuse this water for plants.  Make full use of your washing machine - Half load programmes on washing machines use more than half the water and energy of a full load, so wait until the machine is full before switching it on.  Fix leaking taps - A dripping tap can waste more than  litres of water per week.  Keep a jug of water in the fridge, instead of letting the tap run cold.
